2.label: brothers

2.description: Pyotr Alexandrovitch Miusov, a man very sensitive on the score of money and bourgeois honesty, pronounced the following judgment, after getting to know Alyosha.

6.to: the old man (likely Fyodor Pavlovich Karamazov)

6.description: Alyosha suddenly announced that he wanted to enter the monastery, and that the monks were willing to receive him as a novice. He explained that this was his strong desire, and that he was solemnly asking his consent as his father.

6.from: the old man (likely Fyodor Pavlovich Karamazov)

7.label: friend
7.description: "I’ve really grown fond of you?"

8.label: son
8.description: I feel that you’re the only creature in the world who has not condemned me. My dear boy, I feel it, you know.

0.label: religious figure

1.label: spiritual aspiration
1.description: As soon as Alyosha reflected seriously he was convinced of the existence of God and immortality, and at once he instinctively said to himself: 'I want to live for immortality, and I will accept no compromise.'

1.label: conceptual belief
1.description: If Alyosha had decided that God and immortality did not exist, he would at once have become an atheist and a socialist.

2.label: parent

9.label: influence

10.label: reverence

I’ll sit in a chair and hold my tongue. Now it is for you to speak, Pyotr Alexandrovitch.'

3.label: spouse
3.description: I say to Nikita, my husband...

3.label: spouse
3.description: ...my husband, ‘Let me go on a pilgrimage, master.’ He is a driver.

3.label: spiritual relationship
3.description: ...your little one is surely before the throne of God, is rejoicing and happy...

3.label: counselor/supporter
3.description: Listen, mother...

4.label: relationship
4.description: The Mother refers to Nikita when she says, 'My Nikita tried to comfort me with the same words as you.'

4.label: relationship
4.description: Nikita attempts to comfort The Mother, indicating a close connection: 'He says that to me, but he weeps himself.'

4.label: spiritual guide
4.description: The Elder provides comfort to The Mother, referring to her grief and her child: 'I shall pray for the peace of your child’s soul.'

5.label: Advisory Relationship
5.description: The Elder advises the Mother to go back to her husband, noting that it is a sin for her to leave him.

5.label: Parent-Child Relationship
5.description: The Elder mentions that the deceased child will see from heaven that the Mother has forsaken his father and will weep over her.

5.label: Marital Relationship
5.description: The Mother expresses a longing to return to her husband, saying 'My Nikita, my Nikita, you are waiting for me.'

5.label: Parent-Child Relationship
5.description: Widow Prohorovna talks about her son Vasenka, who has gone to Irkutsk and mentions her concern about not hearing from him.

5.label: Advisory Relationship
5.description: The Elder advises Widow Prohorovna not to pray for the peace of her living son, calling it a great sin akin to sorcery.

6.label: spiritual advisor
6.description: The elder listened to the woman and asked her about her sins.

6.label: spouse
6.description: The woman refers to her deceased husband, indicating she was married to him and had a hard life with him.

6.label: spiritual connection
6.description: The woman seeks absolution from her sin, indicating a relationship with the elder as a representative of God's authority.

7.label: other relationship

7.label: parent
7.description: The peasant woman introduces her baby, saying: 'My little girl, Father, Lizaveta.'

7.label: blessing
7.description: Father blesses the peasant woman and her baby: 'May the Lord bless you both, you and your babe Lizaveta!'

0.label: mother

0.label: daughter
0.description: 'Lise, thank him—thank him!'

0.label: friend
0.description: 'How are you?' the mother went on, holding out her exquisitely gloved hand to Alyosha.

0.label: acquaintance
0.description: 'If any one had looked at Alyosha standing a step behind the elder...'

0.label: friend
0.description: 'It’s at him,' she said, pointing to Alyosha...'

1.description: The elder gives the monk his blessing, indicating a relationship of spiritual guidance.

1.description: The monk has come to seek guidance and support from the elder.

2.label: other
2.description: The monk asked about Lise's healing, indicating a relationship of inquiry and concern for her actions.

2.label: other
2.description: The lady expresses her concern for the elder's health and speaks to him as someone she trusts and respects.

2.label: other
2.description: The elder encourages the lady and assures her of his belief in the sincerity of her suffering.

3.label: friend
3.description: The unnamed character expresses a deep desire to understand faith and seeks answers, indicating a relationship of trust and inquiry with the other character.

3.label: other relationship
3.description: The unnamed character speaks to another about the experience of active love, indicating a relationship based on mentorship or guidance in spiritual matters.

4.label: other relationship
4.description: The lady seeks counsel from the elder about her struggles with loving humanity in the face of ingratitude.

4.label: other relationship
4.description: The elder observes the lady's fervent questioning and discusses insights from a doctor about love and humanity.

4.label: professional relationship
4.description: The doctor expressed his feelings towards humanity in contrast with his inability to love individuals personally.

4.label: other relationship
4.description: The doctor mentioned his growing hostility towards individuals the closer they are to him, illustrating his complex relationship with humanity.

5.label: Mentor/Confidant
5.description: The speaker provides insights and advice to the lady, saying, 'If you do not attain happiness, always remember that you are on the right road, and try not to leave it.'

5.label: Confessor
5.description: The lady acknowledges her feelings and reflections, saying, 'You have revealed me to myself. You have seen through me and explained me to myself!'

6.label: friend
6.description: Lise reminisces, 'He used to carry me about when I was little. We used to play together.'

6.label: friend
6.description: Alyosha's past interactions with Lise indicate a friendship as he said, 'he would never forget me, that we were friends for ever.'

6.label: other
6.description: Lise interacts with the elder, asking 'Why have you put that long gown on him?' indicating a relationship dynamic of confusion and reliance on guidance from the elder.

6.label: other
6.description: The elder listens to Lise and blesses her tenderly, showing a caring interaction between them.

0.label: antagonistic relationship
0.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch delivered him another thrust, almost at the moment of Father Zossima's return.

0.label: intellectual peers
0.description: Miusov, too, was trying to take a part, and apparently very eagerly, in the conversation. But he was unsuccessful in this also.

0.label: relationship of care
0.description: Alyosha, who knew every expression of his face, saw that he was fearfully exhausted and making a great effort.

1.label: professional acquaintance
1.description: Father Iosif is discussing Ivan's article and addressing the elder about it.

1.label: professional acquaintance
1.description: Father Zossima inquires about Ivan's position regarding the Church and State relationship.

1.label: respectful dialogue
1.description: Ivan answers Father Zossima with modesty and reserve.

1.label: professional agreement
1.description: Father Paissy assents with fervor and decision to Ivan's viewpoint on the Church's role.

1.label: disagreement
1.description: Miusov expresses impatience towards Father Paissy's agreement with Ivan, calling it "the purest Ultramontanism!"

2.label: colleagues
2.description: Father Iosif addresses Father Paissy during the discussion, indicating they are both involved in the theological debate.

2.label: acquaintances
2.description: Father Paissy is speaking to Ivan while addressing the elder, suggesting a level of familiarity in their discussion about the Church.

2.label: discussion participants
2.description: Ivan is addressing the elder with perfect composure, indicating they are engaged in a conversation about theological matters.

3.to: the author of the book _On the Foundations of Church Jurisdiction_
3.label: opponents
3.description: The text references a disagreement between Father Iosif and the author regarding the foundations of Church Jurisdiction.

4.label: discussants
4.description: Father Paissy begins speaking, addressing Miusov's thoughts on the Church and State.

4.label: discussants
4.description: Miusov responds to Father Paissy, indicating he has been reassured somewhat by the discussion.

4.label: discussants
4.description: Ivan replies calmly to Miusov's remarks about the potential actions of the Church.

4.label: discussants
4.description: Miusov glances keenly at Ivan, indicating an engagement in the ongoing dialogue.

5.label: conversation partners
5.description: Miusov interrupted Ivan, showing that they are engaged in a conversation about crime and the Church.

5.label: conversation partners
5.description: The elder responds suddenly to Ivan, indicating a dialogue between them regarding views on crime and the Church.

5.label: conversation partners
5.description: Miusov asks the elder, showing he is involved in the discussion with both Ivan and the elder.

6.label: other
6.description: Father Zossima emphasizes the Church's role in 'entering into no compact' with the secular law, indicating a moral and spiritual relationship towards the Church.

7.label: opposition
7.description: Miusov expresses indignation towards Father Paissy's perspective on the Church and State dynamics.

7.label: opposition
7.description: Father Paissy sternly corrects Miusov's misunderstanding of the Church's role.

7.label: observation
7.description: Alyosha observes Miusov's supercilious smile and how Miusov's demeanor impacts their discussion.

7.label: observation
7.description: Alyosha glances at Rakitin and guesses about Rakitin's excitement based on his color in the cheeks.

7.label: inquiry
7.description: Father Iosif inquires about what Miusov finds strange in the discussions regarding the Church and State.

8.label: other
8.description: Father Paissy asked directly, without beating about the bush.

8.label: other
8.description: Dmitri Fyodorovitch came in as a guest so long expected.

0.label: host-guest
0.description: Dmitri kisses Father Zossima's hand respectfully and asks for his blessing.

0.label: servant-employer
0.description: Smerdyakov, the valet sent by Dmitri's father, communicated with Dmitri about the appointment.

0.label: father-son
0.description: Dmitri had been roused to violent anger in his quarrels with his father.

1.label: father
1.description: Dmitri bowed once more... turning suddenly towards his father...

1.label: father
1.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch was taken unawares, he was equal to the occasion... made his son a bow as low in return.

1.label: brother
1.description: Here Ivan Fyodorovitch is smiling at us.

1.label: brother
1.description: Ivan replied at once.

1.label: acquaintance
1.description: Miusov thought it unnecessary to reply to Father Paissy's persistent and almost irritable question.

2.label: friend
2.description: Miusov refers to Ivan Fyodorovitch and his theories as 'eccentric and paradoxical' during a gathering.

2.label: acquaintance
2.description: Dmitri questions Ivan Fyodorovitch's contention regarding crime and immortality.

2.label: interlocutor
2.description: Father Paissy responds to Ivan Fyodorovitch's views by affirming his understanding of the implications of a lack of faith.

2.label: acquaintance
2.description: Dmitri is conversing with Father Paissy about Ivan Fyodorovitch's beliefs.

3.label: parent
3.description: He is my son, flesh of my flesh, the dearest of my flesh!

3.label: parent
3.description: this son who has just come in, Dmitri, against whom I am seeking justice from you

3.label: sibling
3.description: There was a look almost of apprehension in Alyosha’s face.

3.label: spiritual mentor
3.description: the elder raised his hand and would have made the sign of the cross over Ivan

4.label: father
4.description: Dmitri expresses that his father, Fyodor Pavlovich, wants a scandal, implying a father-son relationship.

5.label: father-son
5.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch states, 'And is your father’s blessing nothing to you? If I curse you, what then?'

5.label: father-son
5.description: Dmitri addresses Fyodor Pavlovitch with 'Shameless hypocrite!' indicating a conflict, which is common in father-son relationships.

5.to: the most honorable of young ladies of good family and fortune
5.label: romantic connection
5.description: Dmitri is referred to as having captivated the heart of the girl and is betrothed to her.

5.label: romantic connection
5.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch accuses Dmitri of trying to get money for the purpose of approaching the enchantress, indicating a relationship with her.

6.label: Father-Son
6.description: Dmitri refers to Fyodor Pavlovich as 'father', and expresses anger at being reproached by him for his actions.

6.label: Father-Son
6.description: Fyodor Pavlovich Karamazov scolds his son Dmitri for his behavior, indicating a parental relationship.

6.label: Antagonistic
6.description: Dmitri expresses regret about his brutal treatment of the captain, suggesting a negative relationship based on conflict.

6.label: Antagonistic
6.description: The captain is mentioned as being a victim of Dmitri's violence, indicating a conflictual relationship.

6.label: Possible Romantic Interest
6.description: Dmitri expresses a weakness for the lady, suggesting a romantic connection.

6.label: Romantic Rivalry
6.description: Dmitri accuses Fyodor Pavlovich of being jealous and of forcing his attentions upon the lady.

7.label: father
7.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch suddenly, in an unnatural voice, addressed Dmitri Fyodorovitch, saying he would challenge him to a duel if he were not his son.

7.label: son
7.description: Dmitri Fyodorovitch expresses contempt towards Fyodor Pavlovitch, revealing their contentious dynamic as father and son.

8.label: parent
8.description: Dmitri is Fyodor Pavlovitch's son; Fyodor speaks about Dmitri's actions and decisions regarding his relationships, indicating a familial connection.

8.label: possible acquaintance
8.description: Fyodor addresses Pyotr directly, suggesting familiarity or an acquaintance while challenging him during the confrontation.

8.label: supportive relation
8.description: Alyosha supports Father Zossima when the elder moves towards Dmitri, indicating a supportive or obedient relationship.

8.label: spiritual advisor
8.description: Father Zossima kneels before Dmitri, showing a moment of humility and possibly a spiritual connection as an elder to a troubled soul.

8.label: opponent
8.description: Father Iosif speaks out against Fyodor's statements, showing a relationship of conflict or opposition.

8.label: opponent
8.description: Kalganov expresses strong emotional disapproval of Fyodor's words, indicating a relationship of conflict.

9.label: familial relation
9.description: I said it on purpose to madden you, because you always disclaim the relationship, though you really are a relation in spite of your shuffling.

9.label: negative sentiment
9.description: I am not your relative and never have been, you contemptible man!

9.label: acquaintance
9.description: As for you, Ivan, stay if you like.

10.label: friend
10.description: Miusov asked Ivan abruptly about going to the Superior, indicating a level of familiarity and friendship.

10.label: friend
10.description: Ivan agreed with Miusov that they must explain that their actions were not their doing, showing a mutual understanding and camaraderie.

10.label: implied relationship
10.description: Miusov thought Ivan had 'the conscience of a Karamazov' suggesting familial ties or connections as part of the Karamazov family.

0.label: mentor
0.description: Father Zossima calls Alyosha 'my dear boy' and blesses him for great service in the world.

0.label: student
0.description: Alyosha shows strong emotion regarding Father Zossima's condition, indicating a deep respect and concern.

1.label: mentor
1.description: Alyosha believes in Father Zossima’s words about his approaching end and feels anguish at the thought of losing him.

1.label: acquaintance/friend
1.description: Rakitin is waiting for Alyosha and engages in conversation about the vision of Father Zossima.

1.label: brother
1.description: Rakitin mentions a vision related to Alyosha’s brother, Dmitri, implying a family connection.

2.label: brother
2.description: Alyosha is concerned about Mitya's potential crime when he says, 'If that’s all, you’ve reassured me. It won’t come to that.'

2.label: father
2.description: Rakitin mentions Alyosha's father Fyodor Karamazov being a 'drunken and abandoned old sinner.'

2.label: father-son
2.description: Alyosha reflects on Mitya's feelings towards their father, suggesting a conflict when he speaks of Mitya running at their father 'with a knife.'

2.label: friend
2.description: Rakitin engages Alyosha in conversation, noting that he always speaks the truth and refers to him as 'interesting.'

3.label: brother
3.description: Alyosha is referred to as a Karamazov and directly engages in conversation about Dmitri's character.

3.label: romantic interest
3.description: Dmitri has openly abandoned his betrothed for Grushenka, indicating a romantic connection.

3.label: indirect relation
3.description: Alyosha discusses Dmitri's feelings about Grushenka, acknowledging their relationship indirectly.

3.label: father-son
3.description: Alyosha acknowledges the influence of their father, Fyodor, on Dmitri's character.

4.label: Friend
4.description: Rakitin addresses Alyosha directly, teasing about his purity and thoughts on sensuality, showing a familiarity in their relationship.

4.label: Interest
4.description: Rakitin mentions Grushenka's interest in Alyosha, indicating a relationship, although the nature isn't explicitly romantic in this excerpt.

4.label: Acquaintance
4.description: Rakitin discusses Grushenka's desires related to Alyosha, revealing their connection.

4.label: Acquaintance
4.description: Alyosha responds to Rakitin, indicating they know each other and have a conversational relationship.

5.label: brothers
5.description: If even you are a sensualist at heart, what of your brother, Ivan?

5.label: betrothed
5.description: He has no money, but he’s ready to marry her... to abandon his betrothed, a rare beauty, Katerina Ivanovna.

5.label: romantic interest
5.description: And escape to Grushenka.

5.label: romantic interest
5.description: He’ll carry off Katerina Ivanovna, for whom he is languishing.

5.label: father-son
5.description: The old man, your father, is standing in Mitya’s way now.

5.label: romantic interest
5.description: He’s worse than a tom-cat in love... he has suddenly realized all she is and has gone wild about her.

5.label: romantic interest
5.description: For though she could filch a lot of money from the papa he wouldn’t marry her...

5.label: romantic interest
5.description: Mitya will surrender his betrothed to him to be rid of her, and escape to Grushenka.

6.label: brothers
6.description: Alyosha expresses concern for Ivan and defends him against Rakitin's accusations, indicating their familial bond as brothers.

6.label: associated interest
6.description: Alyosha discusses Ivan's feelings towards Katerina, showing an indirect relationship as Ivan's brother and Katerina's potential romantic interest.

6.label: rivalry
6.description: Rakitin expresses malice towards Ivan, indicating a rivalry or antagonistic relationship.

6.label: potential romantic interest
6.description: Rakitin's anger towards Alyosha might indicate jealousy of Ivan's connection to Katerina Ivanovna.

6.label: friends with conflicts
6.description: Alyosha acknowledges Rakitin's viewpoint, suggesting a complex friendship that includes disagreement.

7.label: dislike
7.description: Rakitin expresses disdain for Ivan, saying he condescends to abuse him and questions why he should like him.

7.label: informant
7.description: Rakitin claims to have overheard Dmitri talking about him, indicating a connection through Dmitri's comments.

7.label: friend
7.description: Alyosha smiles and jests with Rakitin, indicating a friendly relationship.

7.label: relation
7.description: Rakitin reacts defensively to Alyosha's assumption that Grushenka is a relation of his.

7.label: conversation partner
7.description: Dmitri was present when Ivan was discussing Rakitin, making him part of the context in which Rakitin's relationship with Ivan is established.

8.label: relation
8.description: Alyosha states, 'I couldn’t be a relation of Grushenka, a common harlot.'

8.label: friend
8.description: Rakitin addresses Alyosha directly and expresses his irritation towards his comments about Grushenka.

8.label: friend
8.description: Alyosha talks to Rakitin about Grushenka, which suggests a friendship.

8.label: acquaintance
8.description: Miusov is mentioned as driving away and is involved in the scandalous scene with the Karamazovs.

8.label: acquaintance
8.description: Father Isidor is involved in the situation where Alyosha’s father and brother have departed.

8.label: sibling
8.description: Ivan is referred to as Alyosha's brother, indicating a familial relationship.

8.label: parent
8.description: Fyodor Pavlovich is referred to as Alyosha's father.

8.label: acquaintance
8.description: Miusov drives away while interacting with Fyodor Pavlovich, suggesting they know each other.

8.label: antagonistic relationship
8.description: The text mentions a scene involving Fyodor Pavlovich breaking out from the Father Superior, which suggests conflict.

0.label: antagonistic relationship
0.description: Miusov felt ashamed of having lost his temper in response to Fyodor Pavlovitch, referring to him as a despicable wretch and a buffoon.

0.label: courteous relationship
0.description: Miusov reflects that he ought to be friendly and courteous with the monks, including the Father Superior, whom he understands to be a nobleman.

1.label: friendship
1.description: Alyosha, who was attached to him, was distressed to see that his friend Rakitin was dishonorable...

2.label: other
2.description: Miusov conveys Fyodor Pavlovitch's apologies and regrets for his absence due to an unhappy dissension with his son.

2.label: other
2.description: Miusov mentions that he and his brother Ivan Fyodorovitch were asked to convey Fyodor Pavlovitch's apologies.

2.label: other
2.description: The Father Superior expresses regret for Fyodor Pavlovitch's absence at the dinner invitation.

2.label: other
2.description: The Father Superior acknowledges Miusov and the other guests when he receives them.

2.label: other
2.description: Father Superior interacts with Ivan Fyodorovitch during the greeting, highlighting a respectful relationship.

2.label: other
2.description: Father Superior receives Kalganov among the other guests, indicating a respectful relationship.

2.label: other
2.description: Maximov waits aside for Father Superior, showing he is also a guest and respects the hierarchy of the situation.

3.label: unknown relationship
3.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch played a prank at the Father Superior’s dining-room, indicating some interaction despite being disgraced.

5.label: father
5.description: I want to speak my mind. Yes, I am the soul of honor, while in Pyotr Alexandrovitch there is wounded vanity and nothing else. I came here perhaps to have a look and speak my mind. My son, Alexey, is here, being saved. I am his father; I care for his welfare, and it is my duty to care.

5.label: relation
5.description: Miusov, my relation, prefers to have plus de noblesse que de sincerite in his words, but I prefer in mine plus de sincerite que de noblesse, and—damn the noblesse!

6.label: other relationship
6.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch did not understand a word of it... he had uttered his foolish tirade, he felt he had been talking absurd nonsense, and at once longed to prove to his audience, and above all to himself, that he had not been talking nonsense.

6.label: other relationship
6.description: How disgraceful! cried Pyotr Alexandrovitch.

6.label: other relationship
6.description: And so we humbly thank you, honored guest! and he made Fyodor Pavlovitch a low bow.

7.label: opponent
7.description: 'This is too disgraceful!' said Father Iosif.

7.label: opponent
7.description: Father Paissy kept obstinately silent.

7.label: discontented acquaintance
7.description: Miusov rushed from the room, and Kalganov after him.

7.label: discontented acquaintance
7.description: Miusov rushed from the room, and Kalganov after him.

7.to: Unnamed Woman (his wife, the crazy one)
7.label: spouse
7.description: You used to set my wife, the crazy one, against me.

8.label: parent
8.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch commands Alexey to come home to him, saying, 'You come home to me to‐day, for good.'

8.label: sibling
8.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch refers to Ivan as 'my most dutiful son,' which indicates that they are siblings through their father.

8.label: parent
8.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch asserts authority over Ivan, asking for his permission to 'order' him to follow, highlighting a father-son relationship.

8.label: acquaintance/friend
8.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch humorously refers to Maximov as 'von Sohn,' indicating a casual relationship intertwined with humor.

8.label: acquaintance/friend
8.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch expresses delight upon seeing Maximov, inviting him to join them and saying, 'Jump in, jump in!' showing a friendly attitude.

9.label: parent
9.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch was Ivan's father, evident from his remarks and concern about Ivan's actions: 'Well, you are a fellow,' Fyodor Pavlovitch said again.

9.label: child
9.description: Ivan's response and disregard for Fyodor's comments illustrate their dynamic as father and son.

9.label: parent
9.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch speaks about taking Alyosha away from the monastery, indicating his paternal role: 'But I shall take Alyosha away from the monastery...'

9.label: adversarial
9.description: Ivan's violent punch towards Maximov indicates a hostile relationship: 'Ivan, who had by now taken his seat, without a word gave Maximov a violent punch in the breast...

0.label: father
0.description: At the time of our story there was no one living in the house but Fyodor Pavlovitch and his son Ivan.

0.label: spouse
0.description: Grigory decided then, once for all, that 'the woman’s talking nonsense' and that they ought not to leave their old master, whatever he might be, for 'that was now their duty.'

0.label: servant
0.description: Grigory was firm and determined and went blindly and obstinately for his object... for every woman is dishonest, and that they ought not to leave their old master, whatever he might be, for 'that was now their duty.'

0.label: spouse
0.description: Marfa Ignatyevna had obeyed her husband’s will implicitly all her life.

0.label: servant
0.description: In the lodge there were only three servants: old Grigory, and his old wife Marfa, and a young man called Smerdyakov.

1.label: Master-Servant
1.description: Grigory was a most trustworthy man. Many times in the course of his life Fyodor Pavlovitch had only just escaped a sound thrashing through Grigory’s intervention.

1.label: Father-Son
1.description: Alyosha 'pierced his heart' by 'living with him, seeing everything and blaming nothing.'

1.label: Surprise/Revulsion
1.description: It was a new and surprising experience for him, who had till then loved nothing but 'evil.'

2.label: spousal connection
2.description: Grigory had protected Sofya Ivanovna, the poor 'crazy woman,' against his master and any one who chanced to speak ill or lightly of her.

2.label: spouses
2.description: Grigory thought over all his cares and duties alone, so that Marfa Ignatyevna had long grown used to knowing that he did not need her advice.

2.label: spouses
2.description: Marfa Ignatyevna respected him for his spiritual superiority.

2.label: subordinate
2.description: She had given in to him in everything without question or complaint ever since her marriage.

2.label: disliked
2.description: Grigory had detested Adelaida Ivanovna, the first wife of Fyodor Pavlovitch and the mother of Dmitri.

3.label: guardian
3.description: Grigory took Dmitri, then a child of three years old, combed his hair and washed him in a tub with his own hands, and looked after him for almost a year.

3.label: guardian
3.description: Afterwards he had looked after Ivan and Alyosha.

3.label: guardian
3.description: Afterwards he had looked after Ivan and Alyosha.

3.label: parent
3.description: The only happiness his own child had brought him had been in the anticipation of its birth.

character_mapping.the baby: the child of Grigory and Adelaida Ivanovna

3.label: parent
3.description: He announced that the baby ought not to be christened at all.

character_mapping.the baby: unborn child of Grigory Vasilievich Kusmich

3.label: interaction
3.description: Grigory announced this quietly, briefly, forcing out his words, and gazing with dull intentness at the priest.

3.label: godfather
3.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch, who was to stand godfather, he suddenly announced that the baby ought not to be christened at all.

3.label: relationship past
3.description: When Adelaida Ivanovna had run away, Grigory took Dmitri.

4.label: parent
4.description: Grigory laid the child in its little coffin, looked at it in profound grief.

4.label: spouse
4.description: Marfa observed that, from the day of the burial, he devoted himself to 'religion.'

4.label: spouse
4.description: Marfa observed that, from the day of the burial, he devoted himself to 'religion.'

5.label: spouse
5.description: Marfa was awakened by the wail of a new‐born baby. She was frightened and waked her husband, Grigory.

5.label: parent
5.description: An idiot girl, known by the nickname of Lizaveta Smerdyastchaya, had just given birth to a child. She lay dying with the baby beside her.

0.label: parent
0.description: Her father, a homeless, sickly drunkard, called Ilya, had lost everything and lived many years as a workman with some well‐to‐do tradespeople.

0.label: child
0.description: Spiteful and diseased, Ilya used to beat Lizaveta inhumanly whenever she returned to him.

1.label: miscreant-victim
1.description: Rumor pointed straight at Fyodor Pavlovitch, and persisted in pointing at him.

2.label: acquaintance / helper
2.description: Kondratyev arranged to take her into her house at the end of April, meaning not to let her go out until after the confinement.

2.label: spouse
2.description: Grigory took the baby, brought it home, and making his wife sit down, put it on her lap.

2.label: nurse / caregiver
2.description: So Marfa brought up the child. He was christened Pavel.

2.label: guardian / caretaker
2.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch did not object to any of this, and thought it amusing, though he persisted vigorously in denying his responsibility.

2.label: mother / child
2.description: Lizaveta died at dawn after giving birth to Pavel.

2.label: child / mother
2.description: Pavel was christened the child of Lizaveta’s, as she is identified as his mother.

2.label: defender / accused
2.description: Grigory stood up for his master vigorously and provoked quarrels in defense of him, asserting that 'It’s the wench’s own fault.'

2.label: father / child
2.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch invented a surname for the child, calling him Smerdyakov, after his mother’s nickname.

3.label: employer
3.description: Smerdyakov became Fyodor Pavlovitch’s second servant

3.label: household members
3.description: Smerdyakov was living in the lodge with Grigory and Marfa

3.label: household members
3.description: Smerdyakov was living in the lodge with Grigory and Marfa

0.label: parent
0.description: Alyosha's father shouted to him from the carriage, commanding him to return home with his mattress and pillow.

0.label: parent
0.description: Alyosha was fully persuaded that his father might hurt any one else, but would not hurt him.

1.label: anxiety/fear
1.description: He was afraid of that woman, Katerina Ivanovna.

1.label: brotherly
1.description: He had a great longing to run and see his brother Dmitri before that fateful interview.

1.label: friendship
1.description: He reflected that he would not find Ivan, who was so intimate a friend, with her.

1.label: romantic connection
1.description: She was trying to save his brother Dmitri simply through generosity, though he had already behaved badly to her.

2.label: brother
2.description: Dmitri calls out to Alyosha, saying, 'It’s a good thing you looked up. I was nearly shouting to you.'

2.label: brother
2.description: Dmitri expresses joy at Alyosha's arrival and invites him, saying, 'How splendid that you’ve come! I was just thinking of you!'

3.label: brother
3.description: Dmitri led his brother to the most secluded corner of the garden.

4.label: friend
4.description: Alyosha is spoken to by the narrator who expresses a sort of intimate bond while highlighting Rakitin in a negative light, possibly as a contrasting friend.

4.label: friend
4.description: The narrator expresses deep affection for Alyosha, stating, 'I love no one but you!' which indicates a close bond.

4.label: romantic interest
4.description: The narrator mentions being in love with 'one jaded' woman, hinting at Katerina Ivanovna as a love interest causing turmoil.

4.label: unknown/ambiguous connection
4.description: Alyosha expresses intent to visit Katerina Ivanovna, which suggests a connection, but the nature of that connection is not explicitly defined in the text.

4.label: family
4.description: The narrator mentions sending Alyosha to his father, indicating a familial relationship between Alyosha and his father.

5.label: brothers
5.description: Dmitri refers to Alyosha as 'brother' when he says, 'Listen, Alyosha, listen, brother!'

6.label: brothers

0.label: romantic connection
0.description: I began squeezing a girl’s hand, and forced her to kiss me. She was the daughter of an official, a sweet, gentle, submissive creature.

0.label: romantic connection
0.description: She thought, poor thing, that I should come next day to make her an offer (I was looked upon as a good match, too).

0.label: unrequited love
0.description: But I didn’t say a word to her for five months.

0.label: resentment/love
0.description: Now they live happily. Observe that I told no one. I didn’t boast of it.

1.label: romantic interest
1.description: 'That rogue Grushenka has an eye for men. She told me once that she’d devour you one day.'

1.label: friend
1.description: 'You’re the first, except Ivan, of course—Ivan knows everything.'

1.label: friend
1.description: 'You’re the first, except Ivan, of course—Ivan knows everything.'

2.label: general favorite
2.description: She was a general favorite, and of use to every one, for she was a clever dressmaker.

2.label: father and daughter
2.description: The colonel’s second daughter, a great beauty, who had just left a fashionable school in the capital.

2.label: daughter and father
2.description: She too brought the colonel no money.

2.label: family
2.description: She was living with her father and an aunt, her mother’s sister.

2.label: family
2.description: The aunt was simple and illiterate; the niece was simple but lively.

2.label: other relationship
2.description: I was lieutenant in a line regiment, but still I was under supervision, like a kind of convict. Yet I was awfully well received in the little town.

2.label: friendship
2.description: I was intimate with her, not in 'that' way, it was pure friendship.

3.label: Admiration/Interest
3.description: I saw her eyes taking my measure one evening at the battery commander’s, but I didn’t go up to her, as though I disdained her acquaintance.

3.label: Interest/Resentment
3.description: I felt that ‘Katenka’ was not an innocent boarding‐school miss, but a person of character, proud and really high‐principled; above all, she had education and intellect, and I had neither.

3.label: Parent
3.description: Just at that time father sent me six thousand roubles...

3.label: Authority
3.description: I spent my time in drink and riot, till the lieutenant‐colonel put me under arrest for three days.

4.label: friend
4.description: Agafya and her aunt adored their 'Katya' and waited on her, hand and foot.

4.label: friend
4.description: I met Agafya Ivanovna, with whom I'd always kept up a friendship.

4.label: friend
4.description: Agafya was terribly scared in response to the narrator's news about her father.

4.label: other
4.description: There’s a deficit of 4,500 roubles of government money in your father's accounts.

5.label: professional acquaintance
5.description: The old lieutenant‐colonel was taken ill at once, couldn't leave his room for two days, and didn't hand over the government money. Dr. Kravchenko declared that he really was ill.

5.label: business relationship
5.description: He used to lend it to a trustworthy person, a merchant of our town called Trifonov...

5.label: father-son
5.description: I heard all about it quite by chance from Trifonov’s son and heir, a driveling youth...

5.label: subject to suspicion
5.description: But Agafya, remembering what I had told her, had her suspicions.

5.label: savior
5.description: She rushed in, flung herself upon him from behind...

5.label: unidentified relationship
5.description: ...when suddenly the door opened, and facing me in the room stood Katerina Ivanovna.

6.label: requestor

6.label: brother

7.label: romantic interest

1.label: benefactor

1.label: romantic interest
1.description: She offers to be my wife, offers herself to me. ‘I love you madly,’ she says.

1.label: romantic interest
1.description: I wrote her an answer at once, as it was impossible for me to go to Moscow.

1.label: brothers
1.description: Then I wrote at once to Ivan, and told him all I could about it.

1.label: romantic interest
1.description: Yes, Ivan fell in love with her; he’s in love with her still.

1.label: self
1.description: I did a stupid thing, in the world’s opinion; but perhaps that one stupid thing may be the saving of us all now.

2.label: betrothed

2.label: brothers

2.description: The general's wife expresses her opinion about Dmitri when she says, 'I see right through him.'

2.label: rivalry

I tell you that rogue, Grushenka, has a supple curve all over her body... I swear! ‘I’ll marry you if you like,’ she said... She laughed, and she’s laughing still!

5.label: romantic connection
5.description: 'I’ll be her husband if she deigns to have me,'

5.label: romantic connection
5.description: 'Katerina Ivanovna sent for me,'

4.description: Alyosha, here, looks at me and his eyes shine. Alyosha doesn’t despise me.

6.description: Damn it! My mind has never been so darkened before. Excuse me, why, I was thinking, Ivan...

6.description: He’ll kill me! He’ll kill me! Don’t let him get at me!

5.label: employer/employee

21.from: Unnamed character (the person he is addressing)
21.label: judge
21.description: The addressed person is viewed as the narrator's judge, indicating a sense of moral authority or influence: '...he is my judge.'

21.label: reverence
21.description: The narrator recalls Mihail with reverence in prayer, indicating respect for his suffering: 'But I remember in my prayer to this day, the servant of God, Mihail, who suffered so greatly.'

1.label: Adversarial Relationship
1.description: ...when he was deprived of tobacco in prison...

1.label: Advocate Relationship
1.description: ...such a man says, 'I am fighting for the cause of humanity.'

2.label: other relationship
2.description: The monk is reproached for his solitude, but the text suggests that the monk and the people share a common belief: 'The people believe as we do'.

2.label: spiritual relationship
2.description: The text states, 'for the peasant has God in his heart' implying a close spiritual connection.

2.label: opposition
2.description: The text states that 'the people will meet the atheist and overcome him', indicating a relational dynamic of opposition between the monk and the atheist.

4.label: friend/former subordinate
4.description: In my wanderings I met in the town of K. my old orderly, Afanasy. It was eight years since I had parted from him.

4.label: friend/former master
4.description: He chanced to see me in the market‐place, recognized me, ran up to me, and how delighted he was!

5.label: friend
5.description: The monk expresses a loving bond with Afanasy Pavlovitch, stating they exchanged a loving kiss with softened hearts, highlighting their friendship.

5.label: friend
5.description: Afanasy Pavlovitch gazes at the monk in disbelief and sheds tears, indicating a strong emotional connection and friendship.

5.label: spouse
5.description: Afanasy Pavlovitch refers to his wife when he brings her to meet the monk, indicating their marital relationship.

5.label: parent
5.description: Afanasy Pavlovitch introduces his children to the monk, stating, 'Bless them, Father,' indicating he is their father.

5.label: spouse
5.description: Although not directly stated, Afanasy Pavlovitch's calling his wife and including her in the meeting with the monk supports their marriage.

5.label: praying for
5.description: The monk indicates a role of care and benevolence towards Afanasy Pavlovitch's children by saying, 'I will pray for them.'

6.label: servant
6.description: The narrator expresses frustration with the cook, stating: 'the cook had served something too hot.'

6.label: servant
6.description: The narrator expresses frustration with the orderly, noting: 'the orderly had not brushed my clothes.'

6.label: brother
6.description: The narrator reflects on a thought from his dear brother: 'a thought of my dear brother’s, which I had heard from him in childhood.'

9.label: friend/mentor
9.description: Father Anfim taught me to love children.

10.label: other
10.description: My brother asked the birds to forgive him; that sounds senseless, but it is right.

10.label: other
10.description: there would be children and all animals, if you were nobler than you are now.

13.label: potential mentor
13.description: If you had been a light, you would have lightened the path for others too, and the evil-doer might perhaps have been saved by your light from his sin.

13.label: general relationship
13.description: Men are always saved after the death of the deliverer.

13.label: influencer/influencee
13.description: Men reject their prophets and slay them, but they love their martyrs and honor those whom they have slain.

13.label: spiritual connection
13.description: ...for it is a gift of God and a great one; it is not given to many but only to the elect.

14.label: other
14.description: the rich man speaks with Abraham as we are told in the parable of the rich man and Lazarus

14.label: other
14.description: the rich man sees Lazarus in Abraham's bosom

14.label: other
14.description: the rich man beholds heaven and can go up to the Lord

15.label: other
15.description: the righteous in Paradise forgave them, beholding their torments, and called them up to heaven in their infinite love

15.label: other
15.description: I believe that we may pray even for them

character_mapping.the unhappy creatures: the sinful and tormented Karamazov brothers

15.label: other
15.description: Love can never be an offense to Christ

15.label: other
15.description: I confess it, fathers and teachers, and even now I pray for them every day

16.label: friend
16.description: The elder’s death came unexpectedly, with friends gathered about him, indicating friendship between Alexey Fyodorovitch Karamazov and Father Zossima.

0.label: friend
0.description: Father Paissy desired later on to read the Gospel all day and night over his dead friend.

0.label: colleagues
0.description: Both the Superintendent and Father Paissy did their utmost to calm the general bustle and agitation.

1.label: suspicion
1.description: Father Paissy felt for some reason suddenly suspicious of the monk from Obdorsk.

1.label: suspicion
1.description: Father Paissy noticed with inward aversion the presence of Rakitin.

1.label: other relationship
1.description: As appeared later, Rakitin had come so early to the hermitage at the special request of Madame Hohlakov.

1.label: other relationship
1.description: Madame Hohlakov regarded Rakitin as a most religious and devout young man.

2.label: mentor
2.description: Father Paissy shows concern for Alyosha as he finds him weeping and tries to comfort him by saying, 'Why do you weep? Rejoice and weep not.'

3.label: colleagues
3.description: Father Paissy again took Father Iosif’s place by the coffin and began reading the Gospel.

3.label: spiritual influence
3.description: the event...exerted a very strong influence on the heart and soul of the chief, though future, hero of my story, Alyosha.

4.label: mentor
4.description: the deceased elder had said in one of his exhortations

5.label: mentor-student
5.description: That was the very tomb on which Father Paissy had found Alyosha sitting in the morning.

5.label: inspiration
5.description: His tomb was pointed out to all visitors on their arrival with peculiar respect and mysterious hints of great hopes connected with it.

5.label: successor-predecessor
5.description: who had preceded Father Zossima in the eldership.

6.label: other relationships
6.description: Father Paissy continued firmly and distinctly reading aloud the Gospel, apparently not noticing what was taking place around him, though he had, in fact, observed something unusual long before.

6.label: devotion
6.description: the majority of the monks had been devoted to the dead elder.

character_mapping.The monks: the monks of the Karamazov Monastery

6.label: belief
6.description: a layman, an elderly official from the town, known to be a man of great piety.

7.label: friend
7.description: Gentle Father Iosif, the librarian, a great favorite of the dead man’s

8.label: admiration
8.description: Father Iosif... foresaw with distress that something very unseemly was beginning... All who loved the elder... accepted with devout obedience the institution of the eldership...

8.label: reverence
8.description: There was no smell of corruption from the late elder Varsonofy, but a sweet fragrance...

8.label: criticism
8.description: This was followed by a shower of criticism and even blame of Father Zossima...

8.label: judgment
8.description: Yes, clearly Father Ferapont was right in his judgment yesterday...

9.label: dislike
9.description: Father Ferapont particularly disliked Father Zossima.

9.label: perceptive observer
9.description: Standing firm and immovable reading the Gospel over the coffin, Father Paissy gauged most of it correctly in his heart, for he knew the men surrounding him, well.

10.label: peer
10.description: Father Paissy paused in his reading, stepped forward and stood before him waiting.

11.label: Other
11.description: Father Zossima advised the haunted monk to pray and fast, which highlights Father Ferapont's opposition to Father Zossima's views on dealing with evil spirits.

11.label: Other
11.description: Father Zossima's advice is countered by Father Ferapont, who strongly criticizes the approaches taken by the elder regarding the matter.

11.label: Other
11.description: Father Paissy commands Father Ferapont to leave, implying an authoritative and conflicting relationship between them.

11.label: Other
11.description: Father Ferapont expresses his bitterness towards Father Paissy, viewing him as arrogant and dismissive of his humility.

13.label: mentor-mentee
13.description: Father Paissy had previously been the former sovereign of Alyosha's heart and mind, indicating a strong mentor-mentee relationship.

0.label: parental figure
0.description: Father Paissy decided that his 'dear boy' would come back again.

0.label: spiritual relationship
0.description: Alyosha's spiritual condition and his response to Father Paissy's sorrowful question.

1.label: brother
1.description: He remembered afterwards how, on that terrible day, he had entirely forgotten his brother Dmitri, about whom he had been so anxious and troubled the day before.

1.label: friend
1.description: he had forgotten, too, to take the two hundred roubles to Ilusha’s father, though he had so warmly intended to do so the preceding evening.

1.label: mentor
1.description: he revered, Father Paissy himself, for instance.

1.label: mentor/ideal
1.description: the figure of that holy man whom he revered with such adoration.

2.to: the man whom Alyosha loved above everything on earth
2.label: love
2.description: Alyosha’s heart was bleeding, and... the man he loved above everything on earth should be put to shame and humiliated!

2.label: friend
2.description: the harassing impression left by the conversation with Ivan, which now persistently haunted Alyosha’s mind.

2.label: inferiority
2.description: the holiest of holy men should have been exposed to the jeering and spiteful mockery of the frivolous crowd so inferior to him.

3.label: friend
3.description: Rakitin calls out to Alyosha and expresses surprise at his behavior, showing familiarity and a sense of friendship.

4.label: sibling
4.description: Your brother Ivan declared once that I was a ‘liberal booby with no talents whatsoever.’

4.label: sibling
4.description: But, a long while afterwards, Alyosha remembered this.

4.label: friend
4.description: Come to my place.... I shouldn't mind a drop of vodka myself, I am tired to death.

4.label: acquaintance
4.description: By the way, your brother Ivan set off to Moscow this morning, did you know?

5.label: friend
5.description: Rakitin leads Alyosha along the path and expresses surprise at Alyosha's calm agreement to go to Grushenka, indicating a level of familiarity and companionship.

5.label: acquaintance
5.description: Alyosha agrees to go to Grushenka, suggesting he knows her and is willing to visit her.

5.label: acquaintance
5.description: Rakitin mentions the idea of going to see Grushenka and expresses glee at the thought of witnessing Alyosha's downfall, indicating he has a vested interest in her.

0.label: protector
0.description: the merchant Samsonov, who was known to be the girl’s protector

0.label: relationship of interest
0.description: the old man had brought the slim, delicate, shy, timid, dreamy, and sad girl of eighteen from the chief town of the province

0.label: landlady
0.description: the widow had taken in Grushenka as a lodger

0.label: relative
0.description: every one knew that she had taken in Grushenka as a lodger solely to please her kinsman, the merchant Samsonov

0.label: lodger
0.description: the old woman should keep a sharp eye on her new lodger’s conduct

0.label: betrayed
0.description: it was said that she had been at seventeen betrayed by some one, some sort of officer, and immediately afterwards abandoned by him

0.label: daughter
0.description: though Grushenka had been raised from destitution by the old man, Samsonov, she came of a respectable family belonging to the clerical class

1.label: protegee
1.description: Grushenka had succeeded in emancipating herself, while she established in him a boundless belief in her fidelity.

1.label: dependency
1.description: The old man, now long since dead, had had a large business in his day and was also a noteworthy character, miserly and hard as flint. Though Grushenka’s hold upon him was so strong that he could not live without her.

1.label: business relationship
1.description: It was known, for instance, that she had for some time past, in partnership with old Karamazov, actually invested in the purchase of bad debts for a trifle.

1.label: business partner
1.description: It was known, for instance, that she had for some time past, in partnership with old Karamazov, actually invested in the purchase of bad debts for a trifle, a tenth of their nominal value.

2.label: romantic connection
2.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch, who first came into contact with Grushenka over a piece of speculation, ended to his own surprise by falling madly in love with her.

2.label: romantic connection
2.description: When Dmitri too had come on the scene with his love.

2.label: parent-child
2.description: The grotesque and monstrous rivalry of the Karamazovs, father and son.

2.label: friendship
2.description: Grushenka was absolutely and spontaneously open with the old man, and he seems to have been the only person in the world with whom she was so.

2.label: mentor
2.description: the old man gave Grushenka a stern and earnest piece of advice.

2.label: fear-based connection
2.description: Grushenka received Dmitri Fyodorovitch simply from fear because 'he threatened to murder her.'

3.label: friend
3.description: Rakitin introduces Alyosha to Grushenka, indicating familiarity and friendship.

3.label: friend
3.description: Grushenka greets Rakitin and expresses surprise at his arrival, suggesting a friendly rapport.

3.label: friend
3.description: Grushenka recognizes Alyosha and expresses surprise, which implies a friendly relationship.

4.label: friend
4.description: Grushenka turned with a smile to Alyosha. 'Don’t be afraid of me, my dear Alyosha, you cannot think how glad I am to see you, my unexpected visitor.'

4.label: romantic connection
4.description: I tell him that I was going to spend the evening with my old man... I told him I should stay there till midnight, and I asked him to be sure to come at midnight to fetch me home.

4.label: romantic connection
4.description: Mitya believes that I am there, but I came back and have been sitting locked in here, expecting some news.

4.label: acquaintance or helper
4.description: How was it Fenya let you in? Fenya, Fenya, run out to the gate, open it and look about whether the captain is to be seen!

5.label: friend
5.description: Rakitin referred to Alyosha as 'my dear boy' and was eagerly delighted to see him, indicating a friendly relationship.

5.label: acquaintance
5.description: The lady expressed surprise at seeing Alyosha and stated, 'Good heavens, can you have come here to see me!', indicating some level of recognition and acquaintance, though not friendship.

5.label: friend
5.description: The lady's remarks to Rakitin indicate a casual familiarity: 'Eh, Rakitin, if only you had brought him yesterday or the day before!' suggesting they are on friendly terms.

5.label: friend
5.description: Rakitin's grin and playful words: 'Come, don’t you know why you’re glad?' suggest a friendly teasing dynamic between him and the lady.

6.label: friend
6.description: Grushenka expresses kindness towards Alyosha, saying, 'I want you to have something nice.'

6.label: interest
6.description: Grushenka sits on Alyosha's knee and says, 'I’ll cheer you up, my pious boy.'

6.label: acquaintance
6.description: Rakitin comments about Alyosha's sadness by saying, 'He’s sad. The promotion has not been given.'

6.label: acquaintance
6.description: Rakitin addresses Grushenka, referring to her light-hearted teasing of Alyosha.

6.label: acquaintance
6.description: Alyosha does not respond to Rakitin's taunts, indicating a level of familiarity, though strained.

7.label: friend
7.description: Grushenka sits on Alyosha's knee with her arm round his neck and says, 'I can think of Alyosha here, I can look at Alyosha ... smile at me, dear, cheer up, smile at my foolishness.'

7.label: romantic connection
7.description: Grushenka expresses that Dmitri Fyodorovitch has bruised her heart, indicating a romantic entanglement.

7.label: friend
7.description: Rakitin's words, 'Alyosha, she is really afraid of a chicken like you,' indicate a friendship where Rakitin feels comfortable teasing Alyosha.

7.label: acquaintance
7.description: Grushenka acknowledges Rakitin’s presence but dismisses him with a snub saying, 'you’re a toadstool.'

8.label: romantic interest
8.description: I love Alyosha with all my soul!

8.label: romantic interest
8.description: And what about your officer? And the priceless message from Mokroe?

8.label: friend
8.description: Ah, you shameless woman! She is making you a declaration, Alexey!

8.label: friend
8.description: You’re excited, Agrafena Alexandrovna, and not yourself.

8.label: friend
8.description: I’ve talked to him about it. Mitya understands.

8.label: admiration
8.description: I thought that the day before yesterday, as I ran home from the young lady’s.

9.label: friend
9.description: Alyosha refers to Grushenka as 'a true sister' and says 'you’ve raised my soul from the depths.'

9.label: friend
9.description: Grushenka expresses gratitude for Alyosha's kind words and acknowledges her emotional connection to him, saying 'He called me his sister and I shall never forget that.'

9.label: adversarial
9.description: Rakitin taunts Alyosha for rebelling against God and makes derisive comments about his emotional state.

9.label: adversarial
9.description: Rakitin implies that Grushenka is manipulating Alyosha, saying 'And she meant to get you in her clutches, do you realize that?'

9.label: adversarial
9.description: Grushenka defends herself against Rakitin's accusations, stating, 'Hush, Rakitin, because you are telling lies.'

11.label: friend
11.description: Grushenka turns to Alyosha and shares her story, indicating a level of comfort and intimacy in their conversation.

11.label: transactional relationship
11.description: Grushenka promised Rakitin twenty-five roubles to bring Alyosha to her, indicating a financial and social transaction between them.

11.label: acquaintance
11.description: Rakitin is referred to by Grushenka when she states, 'I promised Rakitin twenty-five roubles if he would bring you to me.'

12.label: other
12.description: Rakitin expresses disdain towards Alyosha and questions the basis for loving people, stating, 'What should I like you for?'

12.label: other
12.description: Rakitin shows irritation towards Grushenka and reflects his frustration saying, 'You don’t like us, so hold your tongue.'

12.label: friend
12.description: Grushenka refers to Alyosha positively and suggests that his love is unconditional, stating, 'You should love people without a reason, as Alyosha does.'

13.label: sibling
13.description: And you called me your sister!

13.label: acquaintance
13.description: I bribed Rakitin to bring you.

13.label: associated
13.description: Old Kuzma is the only man I have anything to do with here; I was bound and sold to him.

13.label: past romantic connection
13.description: Five years ago, when Kuzma brought me here, I used to shut myself up, that no one might have sight or sound of me...the man who wronged me.

13.label: friend
13.description: Alyosha, I’ll tell you the whole truth, that you may see what a wretch I am!

14.label: friends
14.description: Alyosha addresses Rakitin directly and discusses their shared experience and thoughts on Grushenka, indicating a level of acquaintance and emotional connection in their friendship.

14.label: admiration
14.description: Alyosha speaks highly of Grushenka, saying she has a loving soul and shows kindness by forgiving others, indicating his admiration for her character.

14.label: mocking friendship
14.description: Rakitin mocks Alyosha's feelings for Grushenka, suggesting there is a playful, yet condescending dynamic in their friendship.

14.label: mutual respect
14.description: Grushenka looks at Alyosha with a tender smile, suggesting a level of respect and gratitude towards him after his defense of her.

15.label: friend
15.description: Grushenka beckoned to Alyosha with a happy smile and asked him to sit down with her.

15.label: acquaintance
15.description: Grushenka turned to Rakitin, speaking to him directly, indicating some level of familiarity.

15.label: friend
15.description: Alyosha was asked by Grushenka to help decide whether she loves the man who wronged her, indicating she confides in him.

15.label: rival
15.description: Rakitin mentions that Grushenka won't get a man like him, implying a competitive relationship.

15.label: superior-subordinate
15.description: Grushenka tells Rakitin that he will black her shoes, indicating a position of power over him.

16.label: friendship
16.description: Grushenka expresses that Alyosha is the first person who has pitied her and that she has been waiting all her life for someone like him, implying a deep emotional connection.

16.label: acquaintance
16.description: Grushenka rebukes Rakitin for his evil tongue and indicates that he never said the words to her that Alyosha has come to say, demonstrating a lesser emotional bond with Rakitin compared to Alyosha.

16.label: acquaintance
16.description: Rakitin scoffs at the idea of Alyosha spending the night with Grushenka, showing his awareness of her emotional turmoil and indirectly highlighting their acquaintance.

17.label: friend
17.description: Alyosha expressed concern and tenderness toward Grushenka, saying, 'What have I done to you?' and attempting to comfort her.

17.label: friend
17.description: Grushenka addresses Alyosha directly, showing emotion and acknowledging her past connectedness with him.

17.label: romantic connection
17.description: Grushenka mentions sending her greetings to Mitya and refers to him as a 'noble heart,' indicating a complex emotional history.

17.label: friend
17.description: Rakitin expresses impatience with her, implying a connection, albeit a strained one.

17.label: friend
17.description: Rakitin's attitude showcases a level of familiarity though he is frustrated, as he says, 'Well, she has no thoughts for us now!'.

18.label: brother
18.description: Alyosha refers to Dmitry Karamazov (Mitya) when Rakitin mentions that Grushenka 'murders' him, indicating a brotherly connection.

18.label: friend
18.description: Rakitin’s interaction with Alyosha implies a friendship, as they are walking and discussing their lives together.

18.label: acquaintance
18.description: Rakitin refers to Grushenka disdainfully, indicating he knows her and her background, implying an acquaintance relationship.

18.label: romantic connection
18.description: Rakitin mocks the situation when he speaks of Grushenka and Mitya, indicating a romantic connection between them.

0.label: mentor/guide
0.description: Father Paissy is reading the Gospel in solitude over the coffin, indicating a spiritual connection and a guiding role for Alyosha.

0.label: religious colleague
0.description: Alyosha falls on his knees and prays before the coffin where Father Paissy is present, showcasing a shared religious environment.

0.label: fellow novice
0.description: Porfiry, the young novice, is described as sleeping in the other room, indicating they belong to the same monastic community.

0.label: menteeship
0.description: Porfiry is likely under the guidance of Father Paissy, who is a senior figure in the monastery.

1.label: admiration
1.description: Alyosha reflects on Jesus' first miracle at the wedding in Cana, feeling it represents gladness for people.

1.label: respect
1.description: Alyosha appreciates that Mary, as the mother of Jesus, knew He had come to bring joy as well as to make a sacrifice.

1.label: mother-son
1.description: Mary asks Jesus to help with the lack of wine, indicating a familial relationship and that she has faith in Him.

2.label: friend
2.description: Father Zossima calls Alyosha to join the feast, indicating a bond of friendship: 'Yes, my dear, I am called, too, called and bidden... Why have you hidden yourself here, out of sight? You come and join us too.'

2.label: self
2.description: Father Zossima is depicted as a character himself, who is also a joyful presence in the vision of the feast: 'He, too, at the marriage of Cana in Galilee....'

2.label: hospitality
2.description: The little, thin old man is there to partake in the joyous occasion, celebrating with the bride and bridegroom at the feast: 'Here are the bride and bridegroom, here is the wise governor of the feast...'

2.label: charity
2.description: Father Zossima mentions giving an onion to a beggar, indicating an act of kindness: 'I gave an onion to a beggar, so I, too, am here.'

2.label: charity
2.description: Alyosha is recognized for his kindness in helping others: 'you too have known how to give a famished woman an onion to‐day.'

3.label: other
3.description: Alyosha brushed against Father Paissy without him noticing it.

0.label: romantic connection
0.description: Dmitri Karamazov knew nothing of what had happened to her, and was at that moment in a condition of feverish agitation and activity, indicating his emotional turmoil regarding Grushenka.

0.label: romantic connection
0.description: Though Grushenka had, it is true, loved him for an hour, genuinely and sincerely.

0.label: rivalry/antagonistic relationship
0.description: For him the whole tormenting question lay between him and Fyodor Pavlovitch.

0.label: conflicted feelings
0.description: Dmitri Karamazov suspected that she, too, was passing through an inward struggle... at moments she must simply hate him and his passion.

1.label: romantic interest
1.description: Mitya had reached this conclusion from his knowledge of Grushenka and her character.

1.label: romantic interest
1.description: That was how it was that he could believe at times that all Grushenka’s uneasiness rose from not knowing which of them to choose, which was most to her advantage.

1.label: father-son
1.description: weighed down by all the hideous horror of his struggle with his own father for this woman

1.label: past relationship
1.description: the man who had been such a fatal influence in Grushenka’s life, and whose arrival she was expecting with such emotion and dread

1.label: past romantic interest
1.description: It is true that of late Grushenka had been very silent about it.

2.label: romantic connection
2.description: He would seize her and bear her away at once to the ends of the earth.

2.label: potential romantic connection
2.description: I have just come to terms with Fyodor Pavlovitch. I am going to marry him and don’t want you.

2.label: antagonistic relationship
2.description: His final conflict with Fyodor Pavlovitch was close upon him.

3.label: romantic connection
3.description: Mitya's desire to carry her away and begin a new life with her himself, at his own expense, highlights his romantic feelings towards Grushenka.

3.label: other relationship
3.description: Mitya reflects on his feelings of having been a scoundrel to Katerina Ivanovna, implying a past connection that is not explicitly romantic but is significant to his conscience.

4.label: romantic connection
4.description: Mitya decided to restore Katerina Ivanovna’s three thousand; he doesn’t want to deceive her and feels a strong obligation towards her regarding the money.

4.label: sibling
4.description: After parting from his brother Alyosha, Mitya felt in his frenzy about his actions and decisions.

4.label: romantic connection
4.description: Mitya mentioned that he would rather be thought of as a robber and a murderer than using Katerina Ivanovna’s money to run away with Grushenka.

4.label: friendship
4.description: Mitya told Alyosha to convey his scoundrel admission to Katerina Ivanovna if it could be any comfort to her.

5.label: romantic connection
5.description: ...he had long entertained the conviction that the old reprobate, who was lying at death’s door, would perhaps not at all object now to Grushenka’s securing a respectable position, and marrying a man 'to be depended upon.'...

5.label: business acquaintance
5.description: Though Mitya knew the merchant by sight, he was not acquainted with him and had never spoken a word to him.

5.label: protector
5.description: ...the merchant who was Grushenka’s protector...

5.label: rival
5.description: ...he believed not only that he would not object, but that this was what he desired, and, if opportunity arose, that he would be ready to help.

6.label: romantic connection
6.description: Dmitri looked upon Grushenka’s past as something completely over... when once Grushenka told him she loved him and would marry him, it would mean the beginning of a new Grushenka and a new Dmitri.

6.label: previous romantic connection
6.description: Dmitri looked upon Kuzma Samsonov as a man who had exercised a fateful influence in that remote past of Grushenka’s, though she had never loved him.

6.label: paternal
6.description: his relations with Grushenka had changed their character and were now simply paternal.

6.label: unfavorable opinion
6.description: Dmitri hardly looked upon Kuzma as a man at all, for it was known to every one in the town that he was only a shattered wreck.

6.label: friendship
6.description: Mitya was seriously persuaded that old Kuzma must sincerely repent of his past relations with Grushenka, and that she had no more devoted friend and protector in the world than this, now harmless old man.

6.label: family
6.description: In the lower story lived Samsonov’s two married sons with their families.

character_mapping.His married sons: Ivan Kuzmich Samsonov and Dmitri Kuzmich Samsonov

6.label: family
6.description: In the lower story lived Samsonov’s two married sons with their families, his old sister, and his unmarried daughter.

6.label: family

7.description: The old man had sent for this giant, not because he was afraid of the 'captain'...

12.description: Samsonov's jealousy of Grushenka influenced his reaction towards Mitya.

5.label: father
5.description: I’m Lieutenant Dmitri Karamazov, the son of the old Karamazov whose copse you are buying.

1.label: romantic connection
1.description: Othello's soul was shattered and his whole outlook clouded simply because his ideal was destroyed.

1.label: rivalry
1.description: The jealous man can forgive extraordinarily quickly ... if only he can somehow be convinced that it has all been ‘for the last time,’ and that his rival will vanish from that day forward.

1.label: rivalry
1.description: the very kisses and embraces he has seen, if only he can somehow be convinced that it has all been ‘for the last time.’

2.label: friend
2.description: Mitya had talked to Alyosha about the 'curve of her body.'

2.label: other relationship
2.description: to get hold of Smerdyakov as soon as possible.

2.description: ...he heard with interest... that his brother Ivan had set off that morning for Moscow.

2.label: other relationship
2.description: ... Fyodor Pavlovitch’s anxiety; he heard with interest, too, that his brother Ivan had set off that morning for Moscow.

3.description: Dmitri Karamazov was terribly distressed about Smerdyakov and wondered what would happen now.

3.label: Romantic interest

4.label: other relationship
4.description: Madame Hohlakov wanted Katerina Ivanovna to marry the 'charming, chivalrously refined Ivan.'

8.label: romantic connection

10.label: acquaintance

10.label: romantic interest
10.description: '...if he did not get hold of the three thousand that would pay his debt to Katerina Ivanovna...'

10.label: brother

10.description: 'Aie! Aie!' cried Madame Hohlakov, alarmed...'

10.label: recognition

3.label: romantic interest

7.description: Oh, a fancy. Why, if you meant to put that bullet in your brain, would you look at it or not?
