5.description: The Lieutenant brought the future wife of Maximov to Russia, indicating a supportive role in her transition to a new life.

5.label: spouse
5.description: Maximov married the lame woman who he refers to as 'my future wife', indicating a marital relationship.

5.label: spouse
5.description: She confessed to Maximov about her lameness after their wedding, emphasizing their married relationship.

6.label: friend
6.description: Kalganov is excited and laughs with Mitya, stating it's natural for Maximov to be low from nature.

6.label: friend
6.description: Mitya follows Kalganov's lead and laughs, indicating a friendly interaction.

6.label: acquaintance
6.description: Maximov makes a statement about his wife and Mitya responds with astonishment, showing they are familiar with each other.

6.label: acquaintance
6.description: Kalganov discusses Maximov's claims and argues about them, showing familiarity.

6.label: spouse
6.description: Maximov mentions both of his marriages and experiences with his wives.

6.label: friend
6.description: Kalganov shows excitement in discussing Maximov's past and relationship with Gogol.

7.label: questioning/antagonistic interaction
7.description: Grushenka flew at him with evident intention of finding fault.

7.label: encouragement to share
7.description: Mitya prompts Maximov to tell his story by asking, 'Come, tell us your story.'

7.label: inquisitive interaction
7.description: Kalganov asks Maximov, 'But what were you beaten for?'

7.label: informative interaction
7.description: Maximov answers Kalganov's question about why he was beaten, providing a narrative context.

7.label: inquisitive interaction
7.description: Mitya responds to Maximov's statement about 'For Piron!' with a puzzled, 'What Piron?'

7.label: dismissive interaction
7.description: Grushenka cuts short the conversation with Mitya by saying, 'Eh, that’s enough! That’s all stupid, I don’t want to listen.'

8.label: friend
8.description: Mitya drinks to Russia and urges Grushenka to join in: 'So will I,' said Grushenka; 'and I would, too ... to Russia, the old grandmother!'

8.label: fellow countrymen
8.description: Mitya calls Pan Vrublevsky to drink: 'And the other pan, what’s his name? Drink, most illustrious, take your glass!'

8.label: friend
8.description: Kalganov joins Mitya in drinking: 'So will I,' said Kalganov.'

8.label: friend
8.description: Maximov responds to Mitya’s toast: 'And I would, too ... to Russia, the old grandmother!'

8.label: commanding presence
8.description: Grushenka commands Mitya to stop quarreling: 'Be silent! Don’t quarrel! I won’t have any quarreling!'

8.label: hostile
8.description: Pan Vrublevsky reacts angrily to Mitya’s comment: 'Can one help loving one’s own country?'

8.label: fellow countrymen
8.description: Both Poles express irritation towards Mitya: 'Panie! shouted both the Poles, menacingly.'

9.label: romantic connection
9.description: Mitya shows eagerness to take Grushenka's side, as demonstrated when he tries to lighten the mood by suggesting they amuse themselves again.

9.label: friend
9.description: Mitya interacts with Pan Vrublevsky by agreeing to the game 'faro' and asking him to take the bank.

9.label: friend
9.description: Maximov asks Mitya for money to stake in the game, which indicates a friendly relationship.

9.label: friendship or potential romantic connection
9.description: Grushenka displays her annoyance towards others and seems to respond positively to Mitya, calling him 'my goddess', which might indicate admiration or affection.

9.label: friend
9.description: The Pole interacts with Mitya by providing clarification on the term 'lite', agreeing to join in the game of faro and addressing him with 'panie'.

10.label: friend
10.description: Mitya and Maximov are playing a game together, and Maximov is delighted at having won a rouble, indicating a camaraderie in their interaction.

10.label: friend
10.description: Mitya and Kalganov are engaged in a game where Mitya expresses remorse for something he said previously, suggesting a friendly rapport.

10.label: friend
10.description: Kalganov speaks to Mitya about losing money to the other players, showing they are part of the same social circle.

10.label: friend
10.description: Maximov enjoys playing games with Mitya and shares a moment of glee over winning, indicating friendship.

10.label: gambling opponent
10.description: Mitya interacts directly with the Pole on the sofa, participating in a gambling game with stakes.

10.label: gambling opponent
10.description: Maximov engages in the same gambling game, showing that he is also an opponent of the Pole.

10.label: gambling opponent
10.description: The Pole on the sofa responds to Kalganov about luck in the game contextually without hostility.

11.label: friend
11.description: Kalganov covered Mitya's money with his hand and shouted, 'That’s enough! I don’t want you to play any more.'

11.label: friend
11.description: Grushenka said to Mitya, 'Give it up, Mitya. He may be right. You’ve lost a lot as it is.'

11.label: romantic connection
11.description: Mitya's astonishment is reacted to by Grushenka, indicating an emotional investment.

11.label: antagonistic connection
11.description: Pan Vrublevsky growled at Mitya after Kalganov's intervention.

11.label: tense interaction
11.description: Mitya went up to the little Pole and slapped him on the shoulder, suggesting a confrontational attitude.

12.label: transactional
12.description: Mitya offers three thousand roubles to the Little Pole in exchange for leaving and not returning.

12.label: companionship
12.description: The Little Pole exchanges glances with Vrublevsky, indicating they are together in this situation.

12.label: transactional
12.description: Mitya includes Vrublevsky when offering money to the Little Pole, suggesting he wants both to leave for good.

13.label: romantic connection
13.description: Mitya recognizes with despair that all is over, indicating his feelings for Grushenka.

13.label: romantic connection
13.description: Grushenka questions Mitya on the matter of money offered for her, indicating her emotional connection with him.

13.label: disdain or confrontation
13.description: Grushenka expresses anger and demands the Pole to speak Russian, indicating a confrontation.

13.label: romantic pursuit
13.description: The little Pole declares that he came to make Grushenka his wife, showing his intentions toward her.

13.label: confliction
13.description: Mitya declares that the Pole is wrong about Grushenka and tries to defend her purity.

14.label: emotional connection
14.description: Grushenka expresses her past feelings of anger and misery regarding a man she has been weeping for five years over, implying a deep emotional connection and unrequited love, which Mitya acknowledges by saying, 'I thought so, too!'

14.label: antagonistic
14.description: Grushenka, upon hearing Pan Vrublevsky's outburst, calls him a 'low harlot', indicating a conflictual relationship, fueled by their respective accusations and emotions during the argument.

14.label: hostile
14.description: Pan Vrublevsky calls Mitya an 'animal' in response to being confronted about his cheating, demonstrating a hostile relationship.

14.label: antagonistic
14.description: Mitya's action of lifting Pan Vrublevsky and carrying him away indicates an antagonistic relationship prompted by a quarrel.

15.label: friend
15.description: Bravo, Mitya! You’re a trump, Mitya!

15.label: friend
15.description: Let him keep it as a consolation.

15.label: friend
15.description: Bravo, Mitya! You’re a trump, Mitya!

15.label: friend
15.description: Lock it, said Kalganov.

15.label: acquaintance
15.description: My dear Dmitri Fyodorovitch, make them give you back the money you lost.

15.label: acquaintance
15.description: _Pani_, if you want to come with me, come.

0.label: romantic connection
0.description: Grushenka was the first to call for wine and wanted to drink to be quite drunk, recalling when they made friends last time: 'Do you remember, Mitya, do you remember how we made friends here last time!'

0.label: romantic connection
0.description: Mitya himself was almost delirious, feeling that his happiness was at hand, in connection with Grushenka.

1.label: romantic interest
1.description: Grushenka looked at Dmitri Fyodorovitch Karamazov from time to time with caressing and passionate eyes.

1.label: friendship
1.description: Dmitri Fyodorovitch Karamazov ran to kiss Kalganov and Maximov.

1.label: romantic interest
1.description: Grushenka sent Dmitri Fyodorovitch Karamazov away with instructions to go and enjoy himself.

1.label: friendship
1.description: Maximov, blissfully drunk, never left Kalganov's side.

2.label: friendship
2.description: Mitya expresses a longing to be with Grushenka, indicating he would go to lengths for her, shown in his reckless actions and concern for her words.

2.label: romantic interest
2.description: Grushenka expresses playful affection towards Mitya by calling him a 'silly boy' and mentioning that she likes reckless fellows like him.

2.label: acquaintance
2.description: Kalganov refers to Grushenka's behavior and comments on her engaging with the party atmosphere, indicating he knows her.

3.label: friend
3.description: Grushenka takes Mitya up to Kalganov and tenderly kisses his forehead.

3.label: friend
3.description: Grushenka asks Mitya to run and find Maximov.

3.label: friend
3.description: Mitya is instructed by Grushenka to go with Kalganov.

3.label: friend
3.description: Kalganov inquires about Maximov's whereabouts showing concern.

3.label: acquaintance
3.description: Maximov is seen with the girls, indicating he is socializing with them.

4.label: friend
4.description: Mitya kisses the dancer, Maximov, indicating a friendly relationship when he says, 'Thanks. You’re tired perhaps? What are you looking for here?'

4.label: friend
4.description: Maximov mutters disconsolately, showing concern for Mitya's earlier comment about being merry, indicative of camaraderie.

4.label: romantic interest
4.description: Maximov expresses a desire to make friends with Marya, indicating romantic interest when he whispers to Mitya, 'That girl there, little Marya, he he! How would it be if you were to help me make friends with her?'

4.label: romantic interest
4.description: Dmitri is emotionally impacted by Grushenka's absence and reflects on his feelings, showing a romantic connection.

5.label: romantic connection
5.description: He had everything to make life happy... but he could not go on living, he could not; oh, damnation! 'To her, to her alone, to see her, to hear her, to think of nothing, to forget everything, if only for that night, for an hour, for a moment!'

5.label: other relationship
5.description: What is it, Trifon Borissovitch? are you looking for me?

5.label: other relationship
5.description: No, sir. The landlord seemed disconcerted.

6.label: romantic connection
6.description: I loved him, you know. How I have loved him these five years...

6.label: friendship
6.description: Mitya, darling, stay, don’t go away. I want to say one word to you...

6.label: former romantic connection
6.description: It must have been his wife that ruined him; you know he threw me up to get married.

7.label: romantic connection
7.description: Grushenka expresses love and longing for Mitya, asking, 'Do you forgive me, Mitya? Do you forgive me or not? Do you love me? Do you love me?'

7.label: romantic connection
7.description: Mitya is described as 'dumb with rapture' gazing at Grushenka, and he kisses her passionately, which signifies his romantic feelings for her.

8.label: romantic connection
8.description: Did you feel how I kissed you when you were asleep just now?

8.label: romantic connection
8.description: I am drunk! I’m drunk as it is ... drunk with you ... and now I’ll be drunk with wine, too.

8.label: friendly
8.description: She was greatly amused by the 'little old man,' as she called Maximov.

8.label: friendly
8.description: He ran up every minute to kiss her hands, 'each little finger.'

9.label: friend
9.description: Grushenka encourages Mitya to give a present and expresses her desire for everyone to dance, indicating a level of camaraderie and friendship.

9.label: friend
9.description: Mitya responds to Grushenka's request to call others to watch her dance, showing his willingness to support her.

9.label: acquaintance
9.description: Grushenka mentions Alyosha saying something that she will remember for life, indicating some form of connection or acquaintance.

9.label: antagonistic
9.description: Grushenka calls the locked up Poles to come out and watch her dance, indicating a relationship that is both dismissive and challenging in nature.

9.label: antagonistic
9.description: Mitya interacts with the Poles in a confrontational manner, calling them names and implying a conflictual relationship.

10.label: romantic connection
10.description: Mitya laid Grushenka on the bed and kissed her on the lips.

10.label: romantic connection
10.description: Don’t touch me.... she faltered, in an imploring voice.

10.label: romantic connection
10.description: I worship you!

10.label: romantic connection
10.description: It must be honorable ... it shall be honorable for the future ...

10.label: conflictual connection
10.description: I’ve stolen money from Katya.... Disgrace, a disgrace!

11.label: romantic connection
11.description: I love you. I love only you. I’ll love you in Siberia....

11.label: romantic connection
11.description: “Close to you,” murmured Mitya, kissing her dress, her bosom, her hands.

12.label: law enforcement officer
12.description: The police captain, Mihail Makarovitch, is present during the confrontation with Mitya as he interrogates him.

12.label: law enforcement officer
12.description: The deputy prosecutor is present in the room and interacts with Mitya regarding the situation.

12.label: legal authority
12.description: The investigating lawyer is also part of the group attempting to get Mitya's explanation.

12.label: law enforcement officer
12.description: Mavriky Mavrikyevitch is the inspector of police whom Mitya knows well.

12.label: unknown relation
12.description: Kalganov is identified as being present at the door but no specific relationship is mentioned.

12.label: unknown relation
12.description: Trifon Borissovitch is also mentioned as being present at the door.

12.label: accuser
12.description: Mihail Makarovitch accuses Mitya, calling him a 'monster and parricide'.

12.label: colleague
12.description: The small young man admonishes Mihail Makarovitch for his behavior towards Mitya.

13.label: parent
13.description: charged with the murder of your father, Fyodor Pavlovitch Karamazov, perpetrated this night.

13.label: adversarial
13.description: drunk, at this time of night, in the company of a disreputable woman, with the blood of his father on his hands....

13.label: official
13.description: I beg you most earnestly to restrain your feelings...

0.label: father-son
0.description: Pyotr Ilyitch carried away a conviction that Dmitri Fyodorovitch could have gone nowhere but to his father’s house.

0.label: romantic interest
0.description: Dmitri Fyodorovitch had run out to look for Grushenka.

0.label: acquaintance
0.description: Fenya begged Pyotr Ilyitch to allow the house-porter to be present, 'because of her misgivings.'

0.label: professional acquaintance
0.description: Pyotr Ilyitch was admitted into Fenya’s kitchen.

1.label: other
1.description: Fenya asked Dmitri Fyodorovitch, 'Why have you got blood on your hands, Dmitri Fyodorovitch?'

1.label: other
1.description: Dmitri Fyodorovitch confessed to Fenya that he had 'just killed some one.'

1.label: other
1.description: Pyotr Ilyitch considered going to Fyodor Pavlovitch to find out whether anything had happened there.

1.label: other
1.description: Pyotr Ilyitch decided to go to Madame Hohlakov to confirm whether she had given Dmitri Fyodorovitch three thousand roubles.

1.label: other
1.description: Pyotr Ilyitch feared that Fyodor Pavlovitch would mock him for inquiring about a possible murder.

1.label: family
1.description: Fenya’s old grandmother confirmed her evidence as far as she was capable.

2.label: Stranger
2.description: Pyotr Ilyitch was a total stranger to Madame Hohlakov, which is noted when she expressed curiosity about the unexpected visit from an official living in the town.

3.label: acquaintance
3.description: I have ventured to disturb you, madam, on a matter concerning our common acquaintance, Dmitri Fyodorovitch Karamazov.

3.label: negative acquaintance
3.description: How much longer am I to be worried by that awful man?

4.label: indirect relationship
4.description: Madame Hohlakov expresses concern for Dmitri Fyodorovitch after discussing the money, saying, 'He must have killed his old father!' and insists on saving the old man from an awful death.

4.label: indirect relationship
4.description: Madame Hohlakov refuses to give Dmitri money, stating, 'I refused to give it him, for he could not appreciate it.' This indicates she has some authority or a caregiving attitude toward him.

4.label: parent-child
4.description: Madame Hohlakov is concerned that Dmitri Fyodorovitch might have harmed his father, indicating a parental relationship.

5.label: acquaintance
5.description: 'Oh, he’s an excellent man, excellent! Mihail Makarovitch, I know him.'

5.label: acquaintance
5.description: 'How practical you are, Pyotr Ilyitch! How well you’ve thought of everything! I should never have thought of it in your place!'

5.label: potential accuser
5.description: 'But if you would write three lines with your own hand, stating that you did not give Dmitri Fyodorovitch money, it might, perhaps, be of use...'

6.label: acquaintance
6.description: Madame Hohlakov mentions, 'I’ve never in my life lent to that unhappy man, Dmitri Fyodorovitch Karamazov...'

6.label: benefactor to beneficiary
6.description: Madame Hohlakov expresses gratitude, 'How grateful I am to you for having come to me...'

6.label: beneficiary to benefactor
6.description: Pyotr Ilyitch feels flattered at seeing her, 'she made a rather agreeable impression on him...'

7.label: eccentric meeting
7.description: this eccentric meeting of the young official with the by no means elderly widow

0.label: parent
0.description: Mihail Makarovitch Makarov is described as having a widowed daughter who lives with him.

0.to: Mihail Makarovitch Makarov's two unmarried daughters
0.label: parent
0.description: Mihail Makarovitch Makarov's widowed daughter is the mother of her two unmarried daughters.

0.to: Mihail Makarovitch Makarov's two unmarried daughters
0.label: grandparent
0.description: Mihail Makarovitch Makarov is the grandfather of the two unmarried daughters.

character_mapping.Mihail Makarovitch Makarov's two unmarri: Darya Mihailovna Makarov and Maria Mihailovna Makarov

1.label: acquaintance
1.description: Pyotr Ilyitch knew for certain that he would meet some of Mihail Makarovitch’s visitors there that evening.

1.label: social acquaintance
1.description: the prosecutor, and Varvinsky, our district doctor, a young man, who had only just come to us from Petersburg after taking a brilliant degree at the Academy of Medicine, were playing whist at the police captain’s.

1.label: spousal relationship
1.description: Ippolit Kirillovitch was married to a fat and childless woman.

1.to: the young investigating lawyer Nikolay Parfenovitch Nelyudov
1.label: professional relationship
1.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch Nelyudov, the young investigating lawyer, who had only come from Petersburg two months before, was sitting in the next room with the young ladies.

2.label: spouse
2.description: Ippolit Kirillovitch’s wife had had toothache for the last two days, and he was obliged to go out to escape from her groans.

2.label: friend
2.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch Nelyudov had been intending for three days past to drop in that evening at Mihail Makarovitch’s, so to speak casually, so as slyly to startle the eldest granddaughter, Olga Mihailovna...

2.label: knows about
2.description: Pyotr Ilyitch was met with the astounding news that old Fyodor Pavlovitch really had been murdered...

3.label: spouse
3.description: Marfa Ignatyevna, the wife of old Grigory

3.label: father
3.description: Grigory was calling out in a weak voice, indicating a familial connection due to the context of the events occurring around Smerdyakov's condition.

4.label: employee
4.description: Marfa continued screaming and calling Fyodor Pavlovitch, indicating she was his servant or employee.

4.label: neighbor
4.description: Marya Kondratyevna woke up at Marfa's screaming and managed to help her, suggesting a neighborly relationship.

4.label: acquaintance
4.description: It happened that Foma had come back from his wanderings and was staying the night with them, indicating that they know each other.

4.label: associate
4.description: Foma ran to the scene of the crime along with Marya Kondratyevna and Marfa, indicating a cooperative relationship in the context of the emergency.

4.label: acquaintance
4.description: Marya Kondratyevna remembered hearing Grigory's scream, indicating she knows him.

4.label: employee
4.description: Grigory is mentioned as having caught hold of Mitya's leg, which indicates the possible context of duty or employment related to Fyodor Pavlovitch.

4.label: associate
4.description: Smerdyakov was in a dire state that suggests he had a relationship with Fyodor Pavlovitch, especially since both were implied to be involved in the ongoing events surrounding the crime.

5.label: employer-employee
5.description: Grigory is mentioned as being 'not allowed even Grigory to come in on any pretext' indicating he works for Fyodor Pavlovitch.'

5.label: romantic interest
5.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch has an envelope addressed to 'my angel Grushenka' indicating a romantic connection.'

5.label: acquaintances or allies in concern
5.description: Marya Kondratyevna ran to the police captain and gave the alarm, arriving only five minutes before Pyotr Ilyitch, suggesting they are both involved in the same concern or issue.'

5.label: victim-perpetrator relationship
5.description: Grigory describes how he was attacked which suggests his involvement in the incident concerning Fyodor Pavlovitch.'

6.label: Other
6.description: Pyotr Ilyitch discusses with others about Mitya's intent to commit suicide, saying, 'You’ll be too late.'

6.label: Other
6.description: Mitya responds to Pyotr Ilyitch's concern about suicide, grinning and saying, 'You’ll be too late.'

6.label: Other
6.description: The prosecutor expresses excitement and concern about Mitya's situation, indicating a professional relationship.

6.label: Other
6.description: The prosecutor addresses other gentlemen, referring to Mitya’s case and connecting it to past criminals.

7.label: friend
7.description: He had spoken to him just before Mitya met the landlord in the balcony, looking for him in the dark, and noticed at once a change in Trifon Borissovitch’s face and voice.

7.label: friend
7.description: Mavriky Mavrikyevitch did as he was told, preserving his incognito, and giving no one but his old acquaintance, Trifon Borissovitch, the slightest hint of his secret business.

7.label: professional relationship
7.description: The doctor remained at Fyodor Pavlovitch’s to make a post‐mortem next day on the body.

7.label: professional relationship
7.description: ...he was particularly interested in the condition of the servant, Smerdyakov.

7.label: professional relationship
7.description: The prosecutor and the investigating lawyer distinctly remembered the doctor’s saying that Smerdyakov could not outlive the night.

0.label: romantic connection
0.description: Mitya says, 'Grusha, my life, my blood, my holy one!' indicating a romantic connection with Grushenka.

0.label: romantic connection
0.description: Grushenka expresses her willingness to be punished with Mitya, saying, 'I will go with him now, if it’s to death!' which indicates a strong bond and emotional connection.

0.label: adversarial relationship
0.description: Grushenka kneels and cries out, 'It was my fault! Mine! My wickedness!' showing her pleading nature contrasting with the police captain's harshness towards her.

0.label: adversarial relationship
0.description: The police captain shouts at Grushenka, 'You’re the chief criminal! You fury! You harlot!' indicating a negative view towards her.

0.label: professional relationship
0.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch, as the investigating lawyer, is attempting to persuade Mitya to drink water, indicating his role in the legal proceedings concerning Mitya.

1.label: father-son
1.description: Mitya (Dmitri) declares he is not guilty of the death of his father, Fyodor Pavlovitch

1.label: assailant-victim
1.description: Mitya admits he is guilty of the blood of another old man but not of his father's

1.label: defendant-victim
1.description: Ippolit Kirillovitch states that Grigory is alive and has recovered from the blows inflicted by Mitya

2.label: mentor/father figure
2.description: Mitya Karamazov says, 'That old man used to carry me in his arms, gentlemen. He used to wash me in the tub when I was a baby three years old, abandoned by every one, he was like a father to me!'

2.label: interlocutor
2.description: Mitya Karamazov directly addresses Nikolay Parfenovitch when he says, 'Excuse me, at this moment it’s quite impossible,' indicating a direct interaction in the courtroom context.

3.label: acquaintance
3.description: Mitya expresses concern about Grigory's potential evidence against him: 'if Grigory has given evidence.... A horrible suspicion! It's awful, awful, I understand that!'

3.label: acquaintance
3.description: Mitya acknowledges having met Nikolay Parfenovitch: 'I believe I've had the honor and pleasure of meeting you, Nikolay Parfenovitch, at my kinsman Miusov's.'

3.label: relationship unspecified
3.description: The text mentions Mitya has a less intimate acquaintance with the prosecutor, suggesting some level of social relationship: 'His acquaintance with the prosecutor was less intimate.'

3.label: acquaintance
3.description: The prosecutor's wife receives Mitya graciously: 'she always received him graciously and had, for some reason, taken an interest in him up to the last.'

3.label: professional
3.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch is directing the secretary on what to write: 'Nikolay Parfenovitch, impressively, and bending down to the secretary he dictated to him in an undertone what to write.'

4.label: father
4.description: Dmitri Fyodorovitch Karamazov expresses his feelings about wanting to kill his father, Fyodor Pavlovitch, and admits to disliking him: 'you disliked your father, Fyodor Pavlovitch... you exclaimed that you wanted to kill him.'

5.label: father-son
5.description: Mitya (Dmitri Karamazov) mentions that he beat his father, Fyodor Karamazov, and swore to kill him: 'I declared them in Father Zossima’s cell.... And the very same day, in the evening I beat my father.'

5.label: acquaintance
5.description: Dmitri Karamazov refers to his interactions with Father Zossima: 'I declared them in Father Zossima’s cell.'

5.label: adversarial
5.description: Dmitri Karamazov is in a position where he is questioned by the prosecutor about the murder of his father: 'Where was he murdered? How was he murdered?'

6.label: romantic connection
6.description: Dmitri Karamazov mentions he was desperately in need of the three thousand for Grushenka.

6.label: antagonistic relationship
6.description: Dmitri Karamazov expresses his intense dislike for the man, stating: 'I couldn’t bear the look of him... but now that he’s dead, I feel differently.'

6.label: social relationship
6.description: Dmitri Karamazov addresses the gentlemen present at the inquiry, stating: 'You have to deal with a man of honor... I’ve been doing filthy things like all of us.'

character_mapping.the gentlemen present: the prosecutor and the investigating lawyer

7.label: romantic connection
7.description: Grushenka was crying and rushed out of the room to him, to her Mitya.

7.label: romantic connection
7.description: Mitya, hearing her cry, trembled, jumped up, and rushed impetuously to meet her.

7.label: friend
7.description: Maximov was sitting with Grushenka, who was crying. Dmitri was in distress about Grushenka's treatment.

7.label: other relationship
7.description: Mihail Makarovitch came to speak to the unhappy man, Dmitri (Mitya).

8.label: friend
8.description: The police captain expresses concern for Dmitri, indicating a warm, almost fatherly feeling for the luckless prisoner, showing a supportive friendship.

8.label: protector
8.description: The police captain took Agrafena Alexandrovna downstairs himself and confided her to the care of the landlord's daughters, indicating a protective relationship.

8.label: romantic connection
8.description: Agrafena Alexandrovna is involved with Dmitri, as the police captain refers to her as a 'good-hearted girl' and suggests she cares deeply for him.

8.label: friend
8.description: Dmitri jumps up and rushes towards the police captain, indicating a sense of urgency and trust in their friendship.

8.label: trusting relationship
8.description: Agrafena Alexandrovna sent the police captain to Dmitri to deliver a message, showing her trust in him to convey her feelings and state.

9.label: romantic connection
9.description: Mitya expresses strong feelings for the woman, stating, 'that woman is the queen of my heart' and describes her love for him as profound, highlighting her willingness to 'go to death with you'.

9.label: friendship / ally
9.description: Mitya thanks Mihail Makarovitch, referring to him as having the 'heart of an angel' and appreciates his role in being a guardian for the woman he loves.

9.label: professional relationship
9.description: Mitya refers to the two lawyers as 'gentlemen' and engages them in discourse about his situation, indicating a formal relationship as they are involved in his legal proceedings.

0.label: friend
0.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch had from the first felt marked respect for Ippolit Kirillovitch, our prosecutor, and had become almost his bosom friend.

0.label: friend
0.description: young Nikolay Parfenovitch was the only person in the whole world whom our 'unappreciated' prosecutor genuinely liked.

0.label: other
0.description: Mitya addressed the gentlemen, which included Nikolay Parfenovitch, during his statement.

0.label: other
0.description: Mitya addressed the gentlemen, which included Ippolit Kirillovitch, during his statement.

0.label: other
0.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch responded to Mitya with enthusiasm, encouraging him.

1.label: audience/participants
1.description: Mitya addresses the group as "gentlemen" and engages with them throughout his explanation.

1.label: adversarial relationship
1.description: The prosecutor interrupts Mitya politely, showing a formal and questioning relationship during the proceedings.

2.label: adversarial
2.description: I can’t expect you to pat me on the head for what I did to Grigory, for one can’t break old men’s heads with impunity.

3.label: friend
3.description: Dmitri Fyodorovitch expresses his appreciation for Nikolay Parfenovitch's kindness, addressing him as a best friend at a moment of distress.

3.label: adversarial
3.description: The prosecutor is interrogating Dmitri Fyodorovitch, showing a formal and confrontational relationship as he seeks to understand why Dmitri needed the money.

3.label: friend
3.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch shows dignified approbation towards Dmitri Fyodorovitch, indicating a respectful friendship or camaraderie.

3.label: adversarial
3.description: The prosecutor maintains a keen watch on Dmitri Fyodorovitch, focusing on his reactions during the questioning process.

4.label: Other
4.description: Mitya mentions that 'Samsonov to whom I went then ...' indicating a connection due to Mitya's interaction with him.

4.label: Romantic connection
4.description: Mitya began to give a minute account of the agonies of jealousy he endured on Grushenka's account, implying romantic feelings towards her.

5.label: romantic connection
5.description: Mitya expressed jealousy towards Grushenka and mentioned his feelings about her, which indicates a romantic relationship.

5.label: family ties
5.description: Mitya refers to Fyodor Pavlovitch as his father, illustrating their familial relationship.

5.label: other relationship
5.description: Smerdyakov is mentioned as bringing information to Mitya, suggesting a connection based on the investigation and mutual interests.

5.label: other relationship
5.description: Mitya recounts a visit to Madame Hohlakov, indicating an acquaintance or social relationship.

5.label: other relationship
5.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch is referred to as a person Mitya spoke to, showcasing an interaction during the investigation.

5.label: other relationship
5.description: The prosecutor is involved in the investigation of Mitya, which creates an adversarial dynamic between them.

6.label: father
6.description: Mitya expresses anger at the idea of killing his father, Fyodor Pavlovitch, when he says, 'that I snatched up the pestle to go and kill my father ... Fyodor Pavlovitch ... by hitting him on the head with it!'

7.label: other
7.description: Mitya is speaking to Nikolay Parfenovitch during the trial and addressing him directly with, 'If you’ll be so kind.'

0.label: father-son
0.description: Mitya describes moments with his father, saying 'my father was alarmed and, for the first time, he saw me then, cried out, and sprang back from the window.'

0.label: romantic interest
0.description: Mitya expresses a longing to know if Grushenka was with his father, indicating feelings towards her: 'he longed so terribly to know whether Grushenka was with his father or not.'

0.label: conflict
0.description: Grigory catches Mitya at the fence, indicating some form of intervention: 'Grigory caught me, when I was sitting on the fence.'

1.label: father
1.description: Mitya expresses anger and confusion regarding the old man who is lying there with his skull broken.

1.label: associate
1.description: Mitya mentions that only he, Smerdyakov, and the dead man knew the signals.

1.label: opponent
1.description: The prosecutor speaks to Mitya, telling him that the door stood open and that the murder was committed in the room.

2.label: father
2.description: Mitya refers to Fyodor Pavlovitch as 'my father' when discussing the signals.

2.label: acquaintance
2.description: Mitya mentions Smerdyakov as someone who knew about the signals, indicating a form of knowledge-based relationship.

2.label: other relationship
2.description: Mitya states that 'Heaven knew' about the signals, implying a spiritual or theological connection.

2.label: interrogator
2.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch is interrogating Mitya about the signals, indicating a relationship of authority and inquiry.

2.label: adversary
2.description: The prosecutor is questioning Mitya with a tone of 'greedy, almost hysterical curiosity,' highlighting a confrontational relationship.

3.label: suspect
3.description: Mitya mentions, 'I’ve been sitting here, shouting that I’m innocent and thinking all the time ‘Smerdyakov!’'

3.label: son
3.description: Mitya refers to Fyodor Pavlovich as 'the old man,' hinting at their father-son relationship.

3.label: potential son
3.description: Mitya states, 'he’s very likely his son, you know—his natural son.'

4.label: Other
4.description: Mitya asks about Smerdyakov during the interrogation: 'And what has he told you, gentlemen—Smerdyakov, I mean?'

4.label: Other
4.description: Mitya describes an altercation with Grigory: 'I had struck Grigory on the head with the pestle.'

4.label: Adversarial
4.description: Mitya experiences irritation from the prosecutor’s interruptions during his statement.

4.label: Adversarial
4.description: The prosecutor conducts the interrogation and interrupts Mitya with questions.

5.label: other relationship
5.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch is questioning Mitya in a legal context, asking him about his actions during the incident.

6.label: potential murderer-victim
6.description: Mitya mentions 'that blood—Grigory’s.... What had I to live for?' suggesting involvement in Grigory's death.

6.label: romantic interest
6.description: Mitya refers to 'the queen of his soul', indicating a romantic connection.

6.label: adversarial
6.description: Mitya's responses to the prosecutor show a confrontational relationship as Mitya expresses contempt.

6.label: business acquaintance
6.description: Mitya tells the prosecutor about his visit to Mr. Perhotin regarding the pistols, indicating a business interaction.

7.label: interrogator
7.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch began, with extreme gentleness, 'where did you get so much money all of a sudden.'

7.label: interrogator
7.description: The prosecutor's brows contracted at the question being asked so plainly, but he did not interrupt Nikolay Parfenovitch.

7.label: interrogator
7.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch went on as though creeping up to the subject. 'Where were you able to procure such a sum all at once...'

7.label: interrogator
7.description: The prosecutor, too, intervened, and again reminded the prisoner that he was at liberty to refuse to answer questions.

8.label: other
8.description: Mitya expresses distrust towards Nikolay Parfenovitch by saying, 'You can’t believe it all simply on my word.'

8.label: other
8.description: Mitya acknowledges that despite his refusal to answer, Ippolit Kirillovitch remains hopeful, shown in the line, '...from Ippolit Kirillovitch’s eyes he saw that he had not given up hope.'

9.label: other
9.description: 'And now allow me to request you to lay on the table everything in your possession...'

9.label: other
9.description: 'You spoke to Mr. Perhotin...'

9.label: other
9.description: 'You spoke to Mr. Perhotin, I believe, of having received three thousand from Madame Hohlakov.'

9.label: other
9.description: 'Oh! you might ask the people here about that.'

10.label: authority
10.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch informed Mitya firmly that it was his duty and obligation to conduct a minute and thorough search of Mitya's clothes and everything else.

0.label: adversarial
0.description: Mitya Karamazov felt that Nikolay Parfenovitch treated him not as an officer but as a thief, saying, 'He treats me not as an officer but as a thief,' indicating a hostile relationship of subjugation and authority.

0.label: observer
0.description: Mitya Karamazov noted their presence as 'Several peasants accompanied the lawyers and remained on the same side of the curtain,' suggesting they were there to witness or support the inquiry against him.

0.label: authority
0.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch commanded Mitya Karamazov without answering his polite request, saying, 'Don’t trouble yourself. We will tell you what to do,' highlighting his authoritative position in the situation.

0.label: colleague
0.description: The secretary mentioned a past incident involving Nikolay Parfenovitch, addressing him as 'You remember Gridyenko, the copying‐clerk,' suggesting a professional relationship where they collaborate.

0.label: colleague
0.description: The secretary referred to Nikolay Parfenovitch with familiarity, indicating a relationship of colleagues, especially as they worked together on the case, discussing pertinent information about the cap and its context.

1.label: interrogator
1.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch is asking Mitya questions regarding the blood on his shirt and the necessity of undressing for evidence.

2.label: acquaintance
2.description: Mitya is frustrated by Nikolay Parfenovitch, feeling he is thought of as a 'puppy' and expressing indignation over being provided with different clothes instead of his own.

2.label: indirect acquaintance
2.description: Mitya curses Kalganov for the clothes provided to him, indicating that they are not his own and that he dislikes wearing them.

2.label: authority
2.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch is in a position where he convinces Mitya to wear the clothes provided, indicating an authoritative relationship regarding the situation.

3.label: other relationship
3.description: Mitya Karamazov addresses Nikolay Parfenovitch directly, expressing disdain in their interaction, as he said, 'He would not turn to Nikolay Parfenovitch, as though he disdained to speak to him.'

3.label: other relationship
3.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch is involved in the examination of Mitya Karamazov regarding the source of the money found on him, as indicated by his statement, 'but having received from you such an uncompromising refusal to explain to us...'

3.label: other relationship
3.description: Mitya Karamazov feels disgraced in front of Trifon Borissovitch, suggesting a familiarity between them, as he thinks, 'He’s come to look at me dressed up.'

4.label: son
4.description: Dmitri Karamazov refers to his father, stating 'the man who opened the door to my father and went in at that door, he killed him.'

4.label: acquaintance
4.description: Dmitri Karamazov says, 'the very thought of having accidentally killed Grigory gave me no peace all night.'

4.label: adversarial relationship
4.description: Dmitri Karamazov expresses resentment towards the 'Gentlemen' saying, 'you’ve sullied my heart!' and refers to them as 'scoffers.'

5.label: unknown conflict
5.description: Mitya shouts, 'It’s either an attempt to slander me, or the hallucination of a madman' about Grigory's statements.

5.label: witness
5.description: Grigory provides testimony about the open door and Mitya's actions.

5.label: official relationship
5.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch is conducting the questioning, indicating a prosecutor-defendant relationship with Mitya.

5.label: supportive relationship
5.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch confirms Grigory's statements and affirms, 'I have cross‐examined him several times.'

6.label: parent-child
6.description: Mitya refers to the envelope that contained money from his father, stating, 'it must be that envelope of my father’s.'

6.label: acquaintance/implicator
6.description: Mitya accuses Smerdyakov of murder and robbery, declaring, 'It’s Smerdyakov, that’s clear, now!'

6.label: parent-child
6.description: Mitya is distressed about his father’s murder, saying 'He must have killed him while I was running away.'

6.from: Grigory (Grigory's full name is not provided)
6.label: servant-master
6.description: Mitya implies Grigory was unconscious during the murder incident, which suggests a service relationship.

7.label: adversarial
7.description: The prosecutor observes Mitya's situation and presents arguments against him, indicating an oppositional relationship.

7.label: legal counsel
7.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch expresses hope that Mitya's confession will influence the proceedings in his favor, suggesting a relationship centered around his defense.

0.label: former betrothed
0.description: I was sent for by Katerina Ivanovna, formerly my betrothed.

1.label: romantic interest
1.description: I’d just come to love another, her, she’s sitting down below now, Grushenka.

1.to: Unnamed Female Character (the one who sent for him)
1.label: financial relationship
1.description: she sent for me a month ago, gave me three thousand roubles to send off to her sister and another relation in Moscow

1.from: Unnamed Female Character (the one who sent for him)
1.label: financial relationship
1.description: gave me three thousand roubles to send off to her sister and another relation in Moscow

1.label: informant
1.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch is involved in questioning him about the money spent

1.label: informant
1.description: the prosecutor is engaging with him regarding his financial disclosure

2.label: other
2.description: Mitya appropriated three thousand roubles belonging to Katerina Ivanovna.

3.label: Romantic Connection
3.description: Mitya refers to Katya as 'Katya' and expresses regret over squandering her money, implying a level of intimacy or romantic involvement between them.

4.label: romantic connection
4.description: I was jealous; I thought then that Agrafena Alexandrovna was hesitating between me and him.

4.label: family ties
4.description: It was all to do with the old man, my dead father.

5.label: brother
5.description: I didn’t dare even to tell Alyosha, my brother, about that fifteen hundred: I felt I was such a scoundrel and such a pickpocket.

5.label: romantic interest
5.description: I might go next day and pay back that fifteen hundred to Katya.

5.label: interlocutor
5.description: chuckled Nikolay Parfenovitch...

6.label: romantic connection
6.description: Dmitri expresses his turmoil over the possibility of going to Katya for money, indicating a romantic link by saying he was on the point of deciding to go to Katya—he shows a personal and emotional struggle connected to her.

6.label: adversarial relationship
6.description: The prosecutor accuses Dmitri of being scoundrel-like and brings up the plan Dmitri is ashamed to admit he considered, showing a combative and accusative dynamic in their interaction.

6.label: implied connection (business/security)
6.description: Dmitri refers to Madame Hohlakov in the context of considering offering security for a loan, indicating a financial relationship rather than a personal one.

6.label: implied connection (business/security)
6.description: Dmitri mentions offering security to the merchant Samsonov, suggesting a business interaction tied to his financial struggles.

7.label: romantic connection
7.description: Mitya expresses guilt and contemplation about potentially asking Katerina Ivanovna for money, emphasizing their emotional and complex bond.

7.label: other relationship
7.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch inquires about Mitya’s confession, indicating a formal role as a prosecutor or interrogator in relation to Mitya.

8.label: self-reference
8.description: Dmitri Fyodorovitch Karamazov often refers to himself as Mitya.

8.label: adversarial relationship
8.description: The prosecutor is questioning Dmitri Fyodorovitch Karamazov about the money he sewed up.

9.label: other
9.description: Dmitri Fyodorovitch Karamazov mentions taking a cap from his landlady: 'I took it from her.'

10.label: Romantic Connection
10.description: Mitya expresses concern for her well-being and insists that she is innocent, saying, 'Surely she need not be ruined with me? She's innocent, you know... Can’t you, won’t you tell me what you are going to do with her now?'

11.label: friend
11.description: Dmitri thanks the prosecutors for their honesty and straight-forwardness, indicating trust and a friendly attitude towards them.

11.label: professional relationship
11.description: The prosecutor assures Dmitri that they will do everything in their power regarding the lady he is interested in, showcasing a formal yet possibly amicable relation.

11.label: indirect relationship
11.description: Mihail Makarovitch is mentioned as potentially having gone downstairs to get tea, indicating a role in providing comfort to the characters, although their direct relationship is not detailed.

0.label: other
0.description: Trifon Borissovitch bore witness that the sum spent by Dmitri Fyodorovitch could not have been less than three thousand.

0.label: self-reference
0.description: Mitya gloomily commented on Trifon Borissovitch's testimony, revealing his own spending habits.

1.label: other
1.description: Trifon Borissovitch discusses the amount of money Dmitri Fyodorovitch had with him and his actions regarding it, implying a financial discussion or transaction between them.

1.label: other
1.description: Andrey is mentioned in a conversation where Dmitri Fyodorovitch supposedly declared he had brought three thousand, showing he is present in Dmitri's discussions.

1.label: other
1.description: Trifon Borissovitch firmly asserts information regarding Dmitri Fyodorovitch's financial situation, displaying an authoritative stance in their relationship.

1.label: other
1.description: Dmitri Fyodorovitch was socializing and treating the chorus in a manner that involved Pyotr Fomitch Kalganov being nearby, indicating social interaction.

1.label: other
1.description: Stepan is noted to have overheard a statement made by Dmitri regarding his spending intentions, which ties him into Dmitri's narrative.

1.label: other
1.description: Semyon, like Stepan, is mentioned to have heard Dmitri's statements concerning his financial dealings, illustrating another layer of social interaction.

2.label: acquaintance
2.description: Kalganov spoke to the lawyers as though he had never met them before in his life, though they were acquaintances whom he had been meeting every day for a long time past.

2.label: respect
2.description: He spoke of Agrafena Alexandrovna with reserve and respect, as though she had been a lady of the best society.

2.label: romantic connection
2.description: Kalganov stated that after the Poles had been turned out, Mitya's position with Agrafena Alexandrovna had certainly improved, and that she had said that she loved him.

3.label: adversarial
3.description: Mitya was roused at once and declared that he would not allow the 'scoundrel' to speak like that in his presence.

3.label: adversarial
3.description: Pan Mussyalovitch at once called attention to the word 'scoundrel' and begged that it should be put down in the protocol.

4.label: transactional
4.description: Mitya had tried to buy off Pan Mussyalovitch and had offered him three thousand roubles to resign his claims.

4.label: witness
4.description: Pan Vrublevsky confirmed the statement made by the Poles regarding Mitya's offer.

5.label: debtor
5.description: Maximov confessed that he had borrowed 'ten roubles in my poverty' from Dmitri Fyodorovitch, and that he was ready to pay it back.

5.label: creditor
5.description: Maximov declared that he borrowed the money from Dmitri Fyodorovitch and was ready to pay it back.

5.label: relationship
5.description: Maximov had taken refuge below with Grushenka, sitting dumbly beside her, implying a form of companionship or emotional connection.

6.label: romantic connection
6.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch asked her, hesitating a little, but preserving the most courteous manner, on what terms she was with the retired lieutenant, Dmitri Fyodorovitch Karamazov.

6.label: acquaintance
6.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch was obviously apprehensive of the effect her appearance might have on Mitya.

6.label: professional relationship
6.description: Mihail Makarovitch himself led Grushenka in.

6.label: concerned acquaintance
6.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch was obviously apprehensive of the effect her appearance might have on Mitya.

6.label: acquaintance
6.description: As she entered the room, Grushenka only glanced for an instant at Mitya, who looked at her uneasily.

7.label: non-romantic acquaintance
7.description: Grushenka mentioned that he came to see her as an acquaintance during the last month.

7.label: jealousy
7.description: Grushenka noted that she had seen Dmitri Fyodorovitch was very jealous of Fyodor Pavlovitch.

7.label: informant
7.description: Grushenka confirmed that Dmitri Fyodorovitch had told her about the three thousand roubles.

7.label: knowledge relationship
7.description: Grushenka knew where the money had come from, that Dmitri Fyodorovitch had got it from Katerina Ivanovna.

7.label: father-son relationship
7.description: Dmitri Fyodorovitch was always expecting to get money from his father, Fyodor Pavlovitch.

8.label: friend
8.description: Mitya got up from his chair, 'have faith in God and in me. I am not guilty of my father’s murder!'

8.label: friend
8.description: 'As he has spoken now, believe it! I know him.'

8.label: acquaintance
8.description: she had heard him tell several people that he had three thousand with him.

8.label: romantic connection
8.description: he had told her that he had 'stolen' it from Katerina Ivanovna.

8.label: professional
8.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch informed her impulsively that she might at once return to the town.

9.label: empathy
9.description: Mitya asks, 'But why is it weeping?' and shows concern for the babe's condition.

9.label: interaction
9.description: Mitya engages in conversation with the driver, who explains the situation of the babe, reflecting their interaction during the ride.

9.label: care
9.description: The driver refers to the child as 'the babe,' showing a semblance of care in his language.

9.label: parent-child
9.description: The tall, bony woman is holding the baby in her arms, indicating a motherly relationship.

10.label: romantic connection
10.description: And I'm coming with you. I won't leave you now for the rest of my life, I'm coming with you, he heard close beside him Grushenka's tender voice, thrilling with emotion.

0.label: official
0.description: Mitya was informed by Nikolay Parfenovitch that he was, from that moment, a prisoner.

0.label: law enforcement
0.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch informed Mitya that he would be escorted at once by the rural police officer, Mavriky Mavrikyevitch.

1.label: defendant to investigator
1.description: Dmitri Karamazov speaks to Nikolay Parfenovitch during the preliminary inquiry about his guilt and acceptance of punishment.

2.label: romantic connection
2.description: Grushenka made a deep bow to Mitya: 'I have told you I am yours, and I will be yours. I will follow you for ever, wherever they may send you.'

2.label: romantic connection
2.description: Grushenka said to Mitya: 'You are guiltless, though you’ve been your own undoing.'

2.label: other relationship
2.description: Mitya shouted, 'Good‐by to you, too, Trifon Borissovitch!' but Trifon Borissovitch did not even turn round.

2.label: other relationship
2.description: Mavriky Mavrikyevitch asked Mitya to get into the cart with somewhat excessive surliness.

2.label: other relationship
2.description: Trifon Borissovitch exclaimed: 'You see what our peasants are, Mavriky Mavrikyevitch.'

3.label: other
3.description: Mitya says to Mavriky Mavrikyevitch, 'I won’t be unruly, I won’t run away from you, old fellow.'

3.label: other
3.description: Mavriky Mavrikyevitch snapped out savagely, indicating a disconnect in their relationship due to Mitya's informal address.

3.label: other
3.description: Mitya shouts 'Good‐by, Trifon Borissovitch!' showing he recognizes him at the moment of leaving.

3.label: other
3.description: Trifon Borissovitch replied in silence, showing a stern and angry disposition towards Dmitri upon his departure.

3.label: friendship
3.description: Mitya warmly says 'Good‐by, dear fellow! I shan’t forget your generosity,' indicating a friendly bond between them.

3.label: friendship
3.description: Kalganov expresses concern for Mitya's well-being, indicating emotional support and friendship, as shown in his actions and words during Mitya's departure.

0.label: mother
0.description: Madame Krassotkin had been married only a year and had just borne him a son. From the day of his death she had devoted herself heart and soul to the bringing up of her precious treasure, her boy Kolya.

0.label: son
0.description: She had loved him passionately those fourteen years...

1.label: mother-son
1.description: Kolya knew how to make even his mother give way to him; he was almost despotic in his control of her. She gave way to him, oh, she had given way to him for years.

2.label: parent-child
2.description: The mother and son went to another district, forty-five miles away, to spend a week with a distant relation.

2.label: friend
2.description: ...he soon made friends. Some of them were living at the station, others in the neighborhood; there were six or seven of them...

character_mapping.the other boys: Dmitri, Alexei, Ivan, and other unnamed boys

2.label: peer relationships
2.description: Kolya maintained stoutly that he would... they laughed at him, called him a little liar, a braggart, but that only egged him on.

3.label: parent
3.description: He confessed long after to his mother.

3.label: teacher
3.description: Dardanelov, a respected and influential teacher, exerted himself in his favor.

4.label: romantic connection
4.description: Dardanelov had been passionately in love with Madame Krassotkin for many years past.

4.label: parent-child
4.description: Madame Krassotkin felt that to accept Dardanelov would be an act of treachery to her son.

4.label: teacher-student
4.description: Dardanelov was severe and strict with Kolya in class.

4.label: peer
4.description: Kolya kept Dardanelov at a respectful distance.

4.label: fondness
4.description: Dardanelov was fond of the boy.

5.label: mother
5.description: Kolya promised on his honor that such pranks should never be repeated, illustrating his role as her son who is influenced by her distress.

5.label: child
5.description: Madame Krassotkin heard of her son’s exploit, showing her role as his mother who is deeply affected by Kolya's actions.

6.label: disdain
6.description: Kolya understood and divined what was in Dardanelov’s heart and, of course, despised him profoundly for his 'feelings'

6.label: child to parent
6.description: His mother still fretted and trembled, but the more uneasy she became, the greater were the hopes of Dardanelov

6.label: respect
6.description: he did not allow himself the remotest allusion to the subject and began to speak more respectfully of Dardanelov before his mother

6.label: gratitude
6.description: the sensitive woman at once appreciated with boundless gratitude

6.label: conflict
6.description: Kolya Krassotkin was the boy stabbed with a penknife by the boy already known to the reader as the son of Captain Snegiryov

6.label: parent to child
6.description: the boy already known to the reader as the son of Captain Snegiryov

0.label: friend
0.description: Madame Krassotkin had let two little rooms to a doctor’s wife and was a great friend of hers.

0.label: employer-employee
0.description: The doctor’s wife set great store by her servant, Katerina.

0.label: employee-employer
0.description: Katerina was the only servant of the doctor’s wife.

0.label: friend
0.description: The friendship with Madame Krassotkin was some consolation to the forsaken lady.

1.label: friend
1.description: Kolya was very fond of the bereaved 'kiddies,' and had already taken them a picture-book.

1.label: friend
1.description: Kolya was very fond of the bereaved 'kiddies,' and had already taken them a picture-book.

1.label: sibling
1.description: Kostya, the boy, aged seven, was very fond of being read to by her (Nastya).

1.label: acquaintance
1.description: Kolya looked, of course, with the utmost scorn on Katerina’s unexpected adventure.

2.label: friend
2.description: Kolya Krassotkin is involved in the dispute between Nastya and Kostya, as he is regarded as an infallible judge by both children.

2.label: friend
2.description: Kolya Krassotkin is involved in the dispute between Kostya and Nastya; he is someone they appeal to for judgment.

2.label: sibling
2.description: Nastya is the elder sister of Kostya, as she often gets the best of their arguments.

2.label: sibling
2.description: Kostya is the younger brother of Nastya, seeking her insight and disputing her claims.

4.label: siblings
4.description: Nastya observes that 'Mother never does whip us' indicating a shared upbringing and sibling relationship.

4.label: siblings
4.description: Kostya and Nastya affirm their fear of crying when left alone, suggesting a close sibling bond.

4.label: friends
4.description: Kolya is entertaining Kostya and Nastya, asking Kostya if he can go out and showing concern for their feelings.

4.label: friends
4.description: Kolya interacts playfully with both Kostya and Nastya, indicating friendship.

3.description: You know I turned him out of the house.... You know all that story, don’t you?

10.label: brother
